name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 1 March 2018.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, just two weeks ago, in a debate in plenary session, we expressed concern about the dramatic situation in Syria. Just a few hours away from Strasbourg, Syrians are suffering, Syrians are hostages to stakes that surpass them. And far from bringing hope, recent developments in recent days keep away any prospect of embellishment. In just a few weeks, the offensive on Eastern Ghouta killed more than a thousand: children, women and vulnerable elderly people. Thousands of injured people are in absolute emergency situations. Finally, the spiral of violence leads to fear the worst: the humanitarian situation within the encircled enclave is likely to worsen rapidly. The news coming from there is terrible. All parties must assume their responsibilities, including, I repeat, the guarantors of the Astana process. No interest, no cause can justify barbarism, ethnic cleansing, massacre of innocent people. On your behalf and on behalf of our Institution, I wish to make a solemn appeal for the immediate implementation of the UN Security Council Resolution. There is an urgent need for a lasting ceasefire, there is an urgent need for the protection of civilians, that the wounded and the sick are evacuated, that aid can be delivered. There is an urgent need for a political solution to be achieved within the framework of the Geneva process. All those who have influence must act to stop this tragedy. Humanity is in perdition in Syria, let us not lose ours. (Applause) I think this message from Strasbourg is a positive message for citizens who are in the midst of fighting, between fighters on one side and on the other. They are the victims: without weapons, they can't get out of town. Hopefully they succeed, but hope also, thanks to this message, that we can do change the situation in the right direction.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, for twelve days the illegal detention of two Greek soldiers in the maximum security prison in Edirne, Turkey, has been continued. It is a case that has shocked Greek public opinion. Yesterday, at a grand rally in Orestiada, the parents of the two lads and residents called for their immediate release. I appeal to the House and to you personally, together with one voice, here in the European Parliament, to demand from the Turkish authorities the immediate release of the two Greek military officers illegally detained in the Turkish maximum security prisons of Edirne. We want your immediate support, Mr. President. The whole public expects it; the parents of the lads expect it. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I will follow the affair personally and ask for the Turkish ambassador for news clearly.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: — Mr President, I think we have been very attentive to what you said about equality between men and women and against sexual harassment. Just because you have referred to the situation of officials of this Parliament, I would like to recall a matter which is extremely worrying. A French official in the General Secretariat had made extremely serious accusations, perhaps totally unfounded — the problem is not there — against a very senior official of this Parliament — whom I do not want to name here. It turns out that the message she sent to all Members of Parliament has been erased by the administration of this Parliament, which is a completely unacceptable intrusion into our personal mail. I have all the elements of this case available to you. I think that if the accusations made by this French official were unfounded, it was entirely legitimate, of course, that the person in question — the very senior official in question — answered or that the Speaker address a reply to the parliamentarians. I think, however, that regardless of the substance of this matter, it was totally inappropriate and inadmissible that the computers of all Members of Parliament were visited in order to have the complainant's message erased. I wanted to remind you of that.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you, Mr Gollnisch, we will check what you said, send me all the documentation in your possession and then we will see.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: Mr President, I request that Parliament, on the basis of Rule 7 of its Rules of Procedure, address the Spanish authorities to concern the situation of former MEP Oriol Junqueras i Vies, the current political prisoner.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Bene verificheremo.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr President! A large number of Members of this Parliament addressed your predecessor, President Schulz, and then directly to you, Mr President, regarding the mural which is displayed in this Parliament a floor below, opposite the hall of deliberations, under the provocative title “Dolorosa”. This unambiguous title offends the faith of very many of us, but it also offends the signs most sacred in European tradition. We were pointing out that this is a sign of indignity. Even if there are people among us consciously professing their spiritual or moral views and agreeing to indignity, let us be degraded, not those whom we love most: let the Mother of Christ not be degraded. Easter is approaching — this is a great opportunity for you to decide to put an end to this manifestation. It appeals to the Lord in the name of your honour, as I have appealed for it immediately after your choice.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I'll talk to the competent Quaestor about this.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: Mr President, I would like to remind Mrs Miranda that in Spain there are no political prisoners, there are criminals, and there are coup criminals, such as the Mr whom you mentioned. He must have had a mental lapse. Yes, yes, show the shirt, Mrs. Miranda! Coup criminals are those people, not political prisoners, who do not exist in a democracy such as the Spanish one.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (NL) Mr President, the request is indeed to attach a short resolution to the debate, because we will undoubtedly hear a number of things already today, but we cannot get all the facts out of the table. I think it is extremely important to show, as a Parliament, that we are taking this seriously, that we are launching an investigation and that we are instructing the Committee on Budgetary Control to report to the April plenary on the occasion of such an inquiry. So a short resolution in which we formulate the mandate of the investigation and put Parliament to work.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (ES) Mr President, we are in favour of the debate because we are in favour of transparency, but we are not in favour of a resolution for three reasons. First, the appointment of Secretary-General is a political competence of the President of the Commission and a resolution would be as long as Parliament would tell the President of the Commission who he can and who cannot appoint Secretary-General. That would not allow the Commission to tell the President of Parliament. Secondly, because that is the responsibility of the Committee on Budgetary Control and we should wait for the Committee on Budgetary Control to say whether it has anything to say. Thirdly, we are here to control the Commission politically, not to monitor the Commission's administrative procedures. We control political procedures. It would be nonsense, it would be absurd if we were more demanding with the Commission's administrative procedures than we are with Parliament's administrative procedures.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Mr President, we discussed this in the Conference of Presidents last Thursday, and it was a little bit the positions that were being developed. I will make you a compromise proposal. I believe that this is a competence of the Committee on Budgetary Control. We are going to have the debate tonight in a few moments, and I think we, as a plenary, can ask — without having to go through a resolution — the chairman of the Committee on Budgetary Control to look into the matter immediately after this plenary, on the basis of the debate we have had. We could then have a well-informed and — I hope — resolution with a large majority on this issue in April. It can be decided that this should be done either under the discharge procedure of the European Commission or in a separate procedure, thus by means of a full exercise resolution, but in any case it can be decided to decide, as a plenary, on this issue in April. That is what I would propose, in a spirit of compromise, so as to bring together a large majority here.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (ES) Mr President, we understand that the Committee on Budgetary Control has indeed to look at this matter like all those involved in discharge. But — I insist — that this House should make a resolution on something which is the political competence of the President of the Commission is as if the Commission is taking a decision on something which is the political competence of the President of Parliament. We still do not understand that there should be a resolution on this matter.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (NL) Mr President, I should like to respond briefly to what has just been said. It is always the responsibility of this Parliament to monitor the integrity policy of the Commission. We do that every year. So those arguments seem completely disabled to me. I note that we all agree that there will be an investigation by the Committee on Budgetary Control. The way in which we make that request — to the chairman of the Committee on Budgetary Control or by resolution — I care less than that the request is made in black and white on your behalf.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Mr President, I take Mr de Jong's statement as an agreement on the compromise proposal I have made. No? Did I misunderstand?

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: As I understand correctly, there is an agreement between Mr Lamberts and Mr de Jong on a proposal: we are conducting the debate today without resolution, we give a mandate to the Committee on Budgetary Control for evaluation and, after its work, we are presenting a resolution — I think it will already be done on Thursday. On Thursday, the Conference of Presidents will also assess the situation and make a proposal for an addition to the agenda. To sum up, we will vote on a motion for a debate without a resolution, but we instruct the Committee on Budgetary Control to assess the situation, then we will have a resolution and a vote in plenary, and on Thursday, at the next Conference of Presidents, we will put the points on the i. The roll-call vote was opened. Everything is blocked, if Mr de Jong accepts a vote by show of hands we can do it.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (NL) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have all, of course, taken note of the shocking reports about the abuse of employees of NGOs, such as Médecins sans Frontières, Oxfam Novib, you name it. I think it is our responsibility to those victims, underage children, helpless women, but also to future needy and, last but not least, to taxpayers in our Member States who are making all this possible with their hard-earned money. That is why I ask your support to talk about this, to have a serious debate on it, and that debate is called 'EU development aid and abuse of NGOs'.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Mr President, I want to apologise to the House because my government has not come up with a definitive document, and this is a great shame because we voted nearly two years ago to leave this sclerotic Union. However, any document that includes ECJ oversight and doesn’t take back control of our fishing waters is unacceptable. There is another reason as well, because any document that has been produced by Mrs Merkel’s people, Mr Verhofstadt, the socialists and the communists opposite, will be totally unacceptable to the British people. So I suggest we vote on that, but do you know what? I can guess what the vote might be.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The S&D Group asked to add, as its third item on the agenda on Tuesday afternoon, after its debate on Mr Viotti's report on the 2019 Budget Guidelines - Section III”, a statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on “Progress on United Nations global pacts for safe, orderly and regular migration and on refugees.” The debate is expected to end with a resolution to be voted on in April. I give the floor to Mrs Maria Joao Rodrigues to make the S&D Group's request.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the reason for this proposal from the S&D Group is very clear, namely that the United Nations is now launching a big initiative to set a global compact on migration and refugees, and Parliament should follow this initiative properly. We believe that during this session we should give the High Representative the opportunity to come here to make a statement and that this should be followed by a proper debate in our session in April. This is our proposal. This initiative also has big implications for one of our concerns, which is to pave the way for a stronger strategic partnership with Africa. We cannot have this strategic partnership if we don’t move on this global compact on migration and refugees.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: – Mr President, I also think that the issue of the Global Compact on Migration is more or less consensual in this House. I fully agree with parts of what my colleague has just said, but we need to send a strong message that this House should be united in finding a global solution. Unfortunately, this week’s plenary agenda is already full, and I would rather have a full debate next month than only a short statement by the High Representative this week, especially as we know that the negotiations in New York are expected to continue until July. If we can put this on the agenda in April and properly prepare a strong and united response from this House, it will also strengthen the position of our own European negotiators in New York. Let’s do the whole thing next session because this week is already so full.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Hon. Wikström therefore proposes to have the same debate, but in April. I do not know whether Mr Rodrigues agrees or if he wants to put your proposal to a vote.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: em nome do grupo S&D. – Mr President, our position is very simple. We agree that this debate should take place in April, because we need to have proper time for this. What is at stake now is some minutes just to have a first statement by the High Representative because she asks us to do so. This is a good moment for her to come with the public position in the European Parliament. But then, yes, the debate as such should take place in April.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Then we can do this way: I can ask, if you agree, the High Representative, to add, during his speech, statements on the matter and then, in April, there will be the debate and the resolution. Can it be a proposition that can go well? Do you agree that I ask? Then I will ask Vice-President Mogherini to add a few comments on the matter being asked, and then the Conference of Presidents will decide how to fix, on the April agenda, also a debate on this topic. (Parliament approves the President's proposal) The ECR Group asked to add, as a third item on Tuesday afternoon's agenda, after the debate on Mr Viotti's report on the “2019 Budget Guidelines - Section III”, a statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on “The prospects for peace on the Korean peninsula, in light of recent developments”. The debate is expected to end with a resolution to be voted on Thursday. I give the floor to Mr Nirj Deva to make the request of the ECR Group.

name: Nirj DEVA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, unusually, I am asking to add to the workload of the House because we have a chance to make a real difference to the peace process in the Korean peninsula. Last Friday, President Trump completely turned his entire policy upside down and decided to negotiate and talk rather than bomb North Korea. He is now facing huge resistance from Americans who are saying that he should not be prepared to go and talk. The South Koreans have sent out a whole delegation of people to fan out around the world to seek support for the peace process. Our Parliament generally, Mr President, is always behind the curve. If we have this debate tomorrow, we will have an opportunity to be at the point or ahead of that curve. Of course, we could have a great debate in April when everything has been settled or the dust has not been settled, but this time we have a chance because we have been talking to the North Koreans for the last two and a half years to be able to be ahead of the curve, to contribute to that process by supporting the initiatives of the President of South Korea, who has done something remarkable in trying to avoid a world war. We need to provide support and tell the people and the President of the United States that the 500 million people represented by this Parliament would like him to talk rather than bomb.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (FR) Mr President, our group has discussed this, and we propose that you organise this debate, if necessary, in April, otherwise everything is improvised. By Thursday, a solid resolution cannot be drawn up.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Deva, do you agree to this, to have a debate in April which is possible, for example? That is my proposal, to ask Ms Mogherini to speak also for two minutes on North Korea, peace and the USA, and then to have a debate in April. It is a proposal from Mr Preda. Are you in favour or not?

name: Nirj DEVA
text: on behalf of the group ECR. – Mr President, I hear what Mr Preda is saying, but we would be closing the stable door after the horse has bolted in April, whilst here we have a real chance to make a huge difference to that process.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: So you want me to put your proposal to a vote? I had made you a counterproposal: to ask, pending a debate in April, to be decided at the Conference of Presidents, the High Representative to express the European Union's position on this argument, but if you want to vote I will vote your proposal.

name: Nirj DEVA
text: on behalf of the group ECR. – Mr President, I am happy to go with whatever the House wants. If you want to have a vote, let’s see.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: So, I am making this proposal: let us vote on Mr Deva's proposal on the request to have a debate tomorrow. But at the same time, if the proposal was rejected, ask Vice-President Mogherini, as we have done on immigration, to inform us about what the Union is doing European. If you agree let's do so. (Malfunctioning voting devices - electronic verification not possible)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: There are problems with this but the vote was very clear. The large majority is against and the proposal is rejected. I ask the plenary: do you agree to a short speech in the longer speech by Ms Mogherini on this?

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item of order of the day is the Commission's statement on the Commission's policy on righteousness, in particular the appointment of the Secretary-General of the European Commission (2018/2624 (RSP)).

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. — Mr President, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen. You have invited me here today to make a statement on behalf of the Commission on the Commission's integrity policy and its functioning, including with regard to the appointment of official Martin Selmayr as Secretary-General of the Commission on 1 March this year. First of all, allow me to explain the context. On 21 February, the Commission took a number of decisions concerning its senior management, in a so-called package. Why are we doing this anyway? We have a decision almost weekly on a larger number of Directorates-General that we know on our services, on a wide range of senior management positions. This would mean unrest in our service. That's why we do this regularly in the package. This is the only way to achieve a balanced overall development in the interests of our institution, for example in terms of different nationalities. We include seniority, age, pension maturity, and the objective of effectively increasing the proportion of women is also a priority. The last package was prepared by my predecessor. It was discussed and adopted by the College at the end of June 2015. Incidentally, in addition to numerous posts of Directors General and Deputies in the Commission, part of the package was the decision that Catherine Day ended her service and that Mr Italians became the new Secretary-General. In fact, at the end of June, a very similar package was to be decided, as was the decision on the current package a few weeks ago. We have an established procedure for this. Allow me to underline three points: we take these decisions on the basis of the European Union Statute. That is our right and our duty. And the same went we again this time. We took this decision by agreement and with the participation of portfolio commissioners, coordinating Vice-Presidents, myself and also the President. All the decisions of the College of 21 February were taken on my proposal, and the decision on the Secretary-General on the direct proposal of our President, just as the responsibility within the Commission. All decisions, including the decision on the new Secretary-General, were approved by consensus of all members of the Commission. May I refer to the minutes of the Commission meeting on 21 February, which we made public — as after each part-session, in accordance with our transparency rules. Secondly, I have no doubt — and it has not been called into question so far — that official Martin Selmayr has all the necessary qualifications for the role of Secretary-General of the European Commission. He has many years of experience in key positions in the Commission, he is an excellent lawyer, he has a high level of communication skills. It is certainly fully suitable for the task. Diligence, talent, qualifications, pro-European attitudes and also political flair are his own. In addition, he has the confidence of our President of the Commission, including my confidence and that of the entire College. With regard to the procedural issues raised publicly in recent days, it can be said that the procedure has also been fully and over time within the framework of this package and then when Martin Selmayr was transferred to the post of Secretary-General, in accordance with Article 7 of the Staff Regulations. First the call for proposals by the Deputy Secretary General, then an assessment center, an external evaluation of candidates, the interview with the Advisory Committee within the Commission and then the interview with the President and with myself one day before the decision. It was a correct selection according to the rules of the Statute, which I also had to secure and ensured as the Commissioner responsible for personnel matters. In the selection of a Secretary-General, neither nationality nor membership of any party, if given. The only focus is on enabling this Office to ensure the best possible functioning of our Authority and to guarantee the work of the President of the Commission. And we consider the candidate, the elected official Martin Selmayr, to be fully suitable for this. In short, we can show you that the formal rules were respected, the procedure corresponded to the same and that the candidate also fully meets our expectations for qualification. That is why we would like to ask you to monitor this decision in this way, but then to accept it.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, there is an indisputable principle: it is within the power of a president to make appointments to highly strategic and political positions. This is the result of a democratic election. Commissioner, thank you for giving us all the explanations, because any appointment should not be a seized power of the senior administration, in defiance of the rules of procedure or through small arrangements between friends, because in this case, what better to feed anti-elite discourse, what better to give Grind to Euroskeptics and maintain the myth of a technocratic Europe headed behind closed doors? In 2014, our group committed to a Europe that is more political, less technocratic, more transparent, closer to the citizen, with a Political Committee taking over administration. Unfortunately, the matter we are debating tonight suggests to our fellow citizens that unelected officials would de facto take over the reins of the institution, with the nose and beard of commissioners who were warned at the last minute. Frankly, we shoot ourselves a bullet in the foot! On the contrary, the legitimacy of senior officials of the Commission, whose competence is undoubtedly, would be reinforced by transparent and fair appointment procedures. However, this affair throws discredit on an entire institution, of which we know is made up largely of talented professionals who are committed to advancing the European project. The European institutions do not belong to senior officials, they belong to European citizens. The former are there to serve the latter and not to serve themselves, for which the Commission is responsible to this Parliament. It would be good to remember that.

name: Arndt KOHN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I am not entitled to judge Mr Selmayr's personal or professional qualifications. Mr Oettinger has just set out in detail what qualifications he has and how the rules were complied with when appointing the new Secretary-General. But why are we not satisfied with this situation? We live in times of Brexit, at times when populists of all stripes are working around the clock to challenge the European project. Actions such as the transport of Mr Selmayr, which give the impression to the outside world that regulations are being stretched to the utmost to fill certain positions with certain people, do not only produce question marks in the eyes of citizens. No, they are water on the mills of European critics and promote incomprehension and rejection among the population. My question to you, Commissioner: how do you intend to restore this lost confidence? In the forthcoming discharge for the financial year 2016, we, as S&D, will table an amendment aimed at finding the most suitable candidates in future application procedures in a fair and transparent manner to fill high-level civil servants. This should not only apply to the Commission. All EU institutions, including Parliament and the Council, should apply this procedure in the future. This is our proposal to regain confidence. I assume that you, Mr Oettinger, have the same objectives and I hope for a good cooperation with you. (The speaker rejected a question about the procedure of the “blue card” by Olaf Stuger.)

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, my Group has tabled a set of questions. Unfortunately, we haven’t received sufficient responses to them from the Commissioner and I hope that he will still go back to those four questions. You have argued that everything was in compliance with the rules: rules are one thing, the other is the impression. Let me add a few more questions to what we originally tabled. I have no special information, everything I have comes from open sources, from the media. Is it true that on 19 February, when Heads of Cabinet met to prepare a College meeting, no mention of the appointment was on the agenda or under any other business, while on 21 February it was there? And that the whole procedure for the appointment of the Secretary-General took just nine minutes, where Mr Selmayr was first appointed Deputy Secretary-General, then the Secretary-General of the European Commission resigned, and then Mr Selmayr was appointed as the Secretary-General? My second question: was he the only candidate, or were there more candidates? My third question, again from the media: is it true that the minutes of the 21 February Commission meeting were amended to include a discussion about the merits of non-existent multiple candidates? Mr Commissioner, there is a lot of interest surrounding that appointment and I think that you should do your best to come out with something which is trustworthy, and you should avoid any feeling or any impression that it was a pre-prepared, politically motivated nomination. Unfortunately, I don’t think that in this case you did your job perfectly.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger has, quite frankly, just made matters a lot worse, coming here and taking MEPs for stupid. Telling us about the wonderful new clothes of the emperor and expecting us to believe it is a stupid strategy, and it just underlines the point that I want to make here today. Today’s debate is not about staff policy; it is about the total lack of political judgment of this Commission and that also applies to the absence of Mr Juncker, who likes to talk about his political Commission, but politics also means political accountability. He should be here to be held accountable for a political decision.  I am left completely speechless at the scene of 28 powerful politicians, selected for the political leadership of this continent but led by the nose by a civil servant. The political Commission of Mr Juncker sheepishly signing on the dotted line. Yes, Commissioner Oettinger, that is what you’ve been doing. If the Commissioners are so easily intimidated by a civil servant, if they act like helpless children when confronted with an unexpected staff decision, then how can we expect them to stand up for the European interests against Trump, for example, in a trade war, or resist pressures from powerful lobbies, or be firm with national governments that violate EU rules?  Maybe that part of the House could have the courtesy to hear me out… (Speaker is pointing to the right) Selmayrgate destroys all the credibility of the European Union as a champion of integrity and transparency in public administration. At a time when public trust in the European project is low, this is devastating, Commissioner Oettinger, and the fact that the Commission has remained deaf to date to criticism shows how disconnected it is from reality.  In conclusion, the Commission will have to choose what is more important: the career of Mr Selmayr or the credibility of the European Union. The appointment of Mr Selmayr was a grave error and it must be corrected, and that is a precondition for our continued support for this Commission.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at a time when the European project is experiencing a growing spite and even hostility, what should we expect from the Commission, the Commission whose last chance is told? Let it reconnect to the crying needs of our societies, that it opens up to the diversity of approaches by leaving at all to the economy, that it leaves the dogmas of single thought, whose failure is obvious, let it come out of the bunker into which it folds day after day. As Maria Montessori might have said in his time, there is an urgent need to mobilise autonomy and initiative among the 33 000 employees of this public service par excellence, which the Commission must be. The assault parachuting of Captain Martin Selmayr at their head was a guilty blindness of Jean-Claude Junker. Nobody questioned neither the intelligence nor the ability to work of the person concerned. On the other hand, it is common knowledge that he is first and foremost the man of a party, whose primary objective is to establish its hegemony over European affairs. Martin Selmayr continues on the path of authoritarian centralization, of caporalisation of civil servants, invited to obedience, rather than creativity, in total disregard for the spirit of collegiality with the aim of having only one line, seeing only one face: his own.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (NL) Mr President, I have to say that I am deeply disappointed by what Mr Oettinger gave us just a few minutes of information. Like the journalists, we are being treated as people's representatives here like children whining about something that has been known for a long time — that the Commission is doing everything right, that the application procedures are fantastic, and that everything and everything is secret and stinks around the appointment of Mr Selmayr. We want to know exactly, step by step: how did the first appointment as Deputy Secretary-General go? How did the second appointment as Secretary-General go? How is it that Commissioner Thyssen was surprised by the proposal for Mr Selmayr as Secretary-General? And don't treat us like little children, because we don't accept that! The same thing happened on February 28 by Vice President Katainen who also said that he would tell us what friendship is when he went for a glass of beer with Barroso. After all, it had nothing to do with Goldman Sachs. Barroso was not a lobbyist at all, but he did record in the register that he had lunch with Goldman Sachs or had a drink. What's the real story? Did Barroso have his agreements with the ad hoc ethics committee that he would no longer lobby for Goldman Sachs, did he not maintain them? In that case, measures must be taken on Barroso. Two instances of integrity, and that is why we have put the issue of integrity policy on the agenda here. We don't want to be treated like children. I must honestly say that last weekend I was reminded very much of what happened to the Santer Commission in 1999. There too was an integrity problem with Madame Cresson and arrogant at the beginning. Because, yes, what are you interfering with? What's going on? It was covered up. And you know the fate of the Santer Commission. My group stands right to a motion mistrust the Juncker Commission if this arrogant attitude continues. During the inquiry that the Committee on Budgetary Control is about to launch, we want all the facts on the table!

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commission. The fast-track appointment of Martin Selmayr to a EUR 20 000 a month job was done without any openness, without any transparency. In fact, his photograph was on the Commission website before the meeting even took place, so well done on that score.  What you have done, I think, is to bring a bit more light onto the Commission. I want the citizens to know that the Commission is the government of Europe. It is unelectable. We cannot vote for them, we cannot remove them, and yet they have the sole right to make law, and people need to understand how their money is being spent. This is Juncker’s favourite bureaucrat, a fanatic, who is now the most powerful bureaucrat in the world, and all of it done without an open procedure. You have done the peoples of Europe a great service. It is the perfect stitch-up. It smacks of nepotism, unaccountable government, abuse of public funds. Thank God the UK is leaving.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (NL) Mr President, I am shocked, but not by Mr Selmayr's appointment procedure. I am shocked by the mistrust I have here in relation to Mr Juncker. For, Mr President, do we not know Mr Juncker as a human being through and through integrity, a modest, no, a submissive director, who completely digs himself away and sacrifices himself for the European citizen? And it is he who, the example for many world leaders, is being smeared here. And, Mr President, I cannot allow that. I can't allow that. I ask for immediate action. My proposal, Mr President, is to cancel next year's elections, the European elections, and to give Mr Juncker the power to elect and appoint Members of this Parliament in a personal capacity.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: — Mr President, Mr Oettinger, you really take us for children by not answering the real questions about the appalling appointment of Mr Martin Selmayr, appointed in one day as Deputy Secretary-General and then Secretary General. The Commission discussed this at length — the spokesperson told us — at a meeting on 21 February, which began at 9.30 a.m., with the call of the press to announce the appointment having left at 9.39 a.m., for a meeting at 10.30 a.m. Fewer than two candidates, because if there had been no candidates, the appointment would have been completely illegal. It needed a man and a woman. A lady, Ms. Clara Martínez Alberola, assistant to Mr. Selmayr, was asked to be a candidate. She kindly did so, she was rewarded, she withdrew her application as soon as the entries closed, in order to leave Mr. Selmayr alone on the track. Who will you make you believe that this procedure is due? There is also one final question, a very important question: how is it that the 27 Commissioners were so benevolent in these indecent manipulations of the procedure? Is it because Mr. Selmayr proposed to increase the transition allowance for former commissioners from 40 per cent to 65% of the last basic salary? Is it because he promised all the former commissioners an office at the Commission, a car with a driver, two assistants, so that they would receive double or triple what they are currently receiving? That is a question that is important for you to answer.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: — Mr President, it is obvious that the position of Secretary-General of the Commission is extremely important. It must ensure the proper functioning of services, balance, the exchange of information between the Directorates-General, the exchange of information with Parliament and, in particular, the implementation of the political decisions of the College of Commissioners, without interfering, without deviating, at all, from these decisions political. The official must implement political decisions, not have opinions, after all. That is why I believe that the procedure must be appropriate, it must be a very transparent procedure, it should encourage the participation of a large number of officials, so that one person who is best suited for this position can be decided. It is only in this way that the Commission is proving its credibility and I believe that the intervention of the Committee on Budgetary Control is extremely welcome here.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: — Mr President, Mr Vice-President, should I reread Article 4 of the Staff Regulations of Officials of the European Union? “Any vacancy in an institution shall be brought to the attention of the staff of that institution as soon as the appointing authority has decided that such employment should be filled”. Why has the post of Secretary-General not been published, contrary to what you reaffirmed here today? Why did Ms. Clara Martinez withdraw her application even before she was heard? Where is the hearing of a man and a woman in your procedure? How is it that staff were not informed on time and time? You, Mr Vice-President, who are so straddling on the observance of all the rules, how can you please yourself with this manifest violation of the spirit and the letter of the law? How can you take the risk of committing this Commission which President Juncker wanted as the last chance Commission, which today fuels Euroskeptic speeches, even in its ranks, when we need it to be the guardian of the Treaties? How can you violate the spirit of institutions that make those who work in them are not there to serve themselves but to work for the citizens — the people we represent? Being at the service of the citizens is what we have to do in an exemplary way, here in the face of the mistakes within the European Commission, but we must, of course, also do so with the same vigilance in our own institution, as we know. So we say to you, Mr Vice-President: cease these untruths! Regardless of Mr. Selmayr's qualifications, he did not have the legal qualifications in terms of employment to hold those positions and your ability to promote women by asking this Deputy Secretary General to withdraw his candidacy, even before having heard it is not worthy of promoting gender equality.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, Brussels has a negative sound, a sound of nepotism and good care for yourself in many European citizens. That is exactly what President Juncker has now done. Push boyfriend Selmayr forward and take good care of him. After 60 years of European Union, little seems to have changed. Heinrich Heine was right: “Es ist eine alte Geschichte, doch bleibt sie immer neu”. Juncker is always there as the chickens to accuse Member States and others of leaving for responsibility and not being transparent. He is now doing the same thing and hiding behind spokesmen who say that everything has been done with religious correctness. You have to have the guts! Commissioner Oettinger's stunningly simplistic answer now shows that the Commission is lacking any political antenna. And Mr. Selmayr is now “burnt Brussels praise” and everyone knows that it cannot be digested. A new procedure is starting today in Mr Italianer's succession. Only in this way can the damage and disgrace of this new case of Brussels cronyism be limited to a little bit.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: – Mr President, first of all we should ask where President Juncker is, because he, not you, should be the best person to answer questions about the double promotion of Mr Selmayr, which was approved at the College meeting on 21 February. But, I have some questions for you, Commissioner Oettinger. How long beforehand were you informed that Mr Selmayr was the only candidate for this post? To many observers giving Mr Selmayr a double promotion did not respect at least two articles of the Statute for EU civil servants. Article 29 requires an internal competition for the vacant post of Deputy Secretary—General. Mr Selmayr only had the grade of director and he was appointed Deputy Secretary—General. Commissioner Oettinger, for how long did he hold this post? Article 4 requires the appointing authority and the staff of the Commission to be informed. This was not the case. So, Commissioner Oettinger, was it a fake internal competition? It seems an abuse of power. I welcome the fact that the EU Ombudsman is analysing this affair. Colleagues, such behaviours and abuses of power are fuelling anti—European sentiment all over Europe.

name: Bart STAES
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this is a debate on ethics and integrity. You say all the rules have been followed, but whoever studies the file more closely knows that this whole file stinks. Firstly, the appointment of Deputy Secretary-General. That procedure has been carried out in an extremely fast way. Vacancy: 31 January. External evaluation: 15 February. Discussion with the Advisory Committee: 16 February. Interview with you and Mr. Juncker: February 20th. Appointment as Deputy Secretary-General: 21 February. A world record! Secondly, the vacancy has not been treated in a fair way. There were no multiple candidates.Thirdly, the vacancy is not open and transparent. Fourthly, the appointment of Secretary-General on 21 February was carried out in a way like a deus ex machina: not announced, not on the agenda, without any document on the table for the 28 Commissioners. This matter needs to be investigated, Mr Oettinger! And that will happen in the Committee on Budgetary Control! You don't have to pretend we're little children! We want to know what has happened and we do not accept that senior officials should be chased through in such a way, in such an unfair manner!

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are here discussing a grey official, Selmayr, whom no European citizen knows, however. Why? Because Selmayr, in a moment, found himself sitting in one of the heaviest armchairs in the European Commission. The problem is that we know who wanted to put in charge of the Cabinet of the Juncker office the German Selmayr, and who did the interests. Now, I do not dispute the formal correctness of the appointment itself, but rather the political role of the Commission and its President, and above all I would like to know the consideration that ethics must have in public life. At this point I wonder and ask you, my fellow Members: Are the President of the Commission and the Commissioners just simple technicians or are they politicians? Because if they are politicians — something that President Juncker has repeatedly reiterated — how they respond for their conduct to the citizens who have not elected them but who suffer their own decisions? Politicians, especially those at the head of institutions, must act with integrity, discipline, honour, always behave ethically blameless. All their acts must not only be, but also appear blameless. There can be no doubt about their surgery. So where, in this case, are the ethics and transparency, which you, Commissioner, mentioned before? What are the mechanisms of political sanction in the face of these attitudes and behaviours, given that neither you, Commissioner Oettinger, or even President Juncker, have been directly elected by citizens, and is not an individual motion of no confidence expected? Above all, where is President Juncker? The vote in Italy showed that citizens no longer want this Europe, closed in a fort of recommended, German interests and lobbyists. From Italy there is a strong wind of change, which you can no longer ignore.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: — Mr President, yes, the appointment of Mr Selmayr as Secretary-General of the European Commission is scandalous. Scandalous because this support from Mrs Merkel adds to the long list of Germans who are misappropriately appointed to key positions in European bodies. Scandalous because this totally arbitrary appointment, in defiance of all the recruitment rules in force in this institution, enshrines the triumph of the bureaucratic superstructure over the politicians we are. While the European Union continues to give lessons in human rights, respect for the rule of law and democracy to the entire land, now the former Prime Minister of a tax haven wants to impose his head of cabinet at the head of the administration of the European executive. Instead of coming here to explain this, Mr Juncker is sending us Mr Oettinger, the German Commissioner also chosen by Mrs Merkel. What a contempt for Parliament and the citizens we represent! It is with this same contempt that the unelected bureaucrats of the Commission, who have exorbitant power, allow themselves to challenge both legal and legitimate decisions of democratically elected governments such as Poland or Hungary.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. I didn't know how many of you and of us were keen to learn into the depths of the Statute. I'm looking forward to it. I would like to invite us to contribute to the objective of the debate. The Committee on Budgetary Control will ask questions, the spokespersons will decide on this in a week today, and then we will all ask the questions that concern us. Plenary deliberation is usually preceded by committee deliberation. It might have been good to stick to it in that case. Every employee is welcome to ask questions here. I believe that there is an urgent need to contribute to the objective. I want to break a spear for the statute, for parole promotion, for equal opportunities — here in the House, too. I know that the civil servants rely on it and count on us. I therefore take note of the Commissioner's statement that the rules and procedures of the Statute have been respected. There were even two assessment centers. We do not have a status change for former Commissioners, Commissioner — it would be important for you to say this again — so no chauffeur, no office, no staff and no transitional allowance. It would be very important to hear about it from you. And I also note that no one doubted that the nominee could. I believe it is also always important for promotions to ensure that the nominated person can. We will clarify the rest in the Committee on Budgetary Control and hopefully then bring about a resolution.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Mr President, I support the demand that, now that we are also in the context of discharge, the Committee on Budgetary Control should give Mr Oettinger the necessary hearing: we have the capacity and we have already requested it. But anyway, Mr Oettinger, I wanted to say that I have been asking for years in this Parliament for years — and in the context of discharge, moreover — some changes and some sponge of appointments to senior officials without having ever ignoRED us. And when, at last, this comes, it turns out that I can't even rejoice or we can be glad because the whole procedure is contaminated by that express decision on the appointment of the Secretary-General, which is inadmissible even if it is legal and even legitimate, but which has been done in such a way that right now has placed us in the middle of a a storm that prevents us from focusing on the essentials — Brexit and its consequences, the 2020 budgets, the social rights pillar, migration policy,... in short, the essential issues of the European Union — and instead of the essentials, we are talking about the functioning, the malfunction, the opaque functioning of institutions. In view of what happened, therefore, in that College of Commissioners — which I must remember that everyone approved it, even if then in the corridors they cry, complain and say other things — we in Parliament need to take some decisions in this sterile debate. I, of course, agree that, in the context of discharge and the Committee on Budgetary Control, which is where we usually control, we will certainly need to do that hearing and that in-depth inspection. And I would also ask you, Mr Oettinger, since I know that you are able to do it, to tell us here that, before the end of this year — which is what we socialists have asked for —, The Commission will present us with a proposal for the appointment of senior representatives and senior officials which is definitely more transparent, which is up to the time and also respects the equal rights of civil servants. I believe that we all deserve it, and also Europe for its future.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: Mr President! One must be both blind, mute and deaf to believe in Commissioner Oettinger's assurances that this designation has been done both according to the spirit and the letter of the rules. That is why I also feel sorry for the Commissioner today. I feel sorry that President Jean-Claude Juncker has chosen to send a pot-boy to explain this designation rather than appear in his own person and explain to Parliament why it would absolutely insist on discrediting the Commission's highest level of officials with political designations. This is something that will harm the Commission not just today, when we discuss this designation, but also in the years to come. If European citizens do not believe fundamentally that the senior officials of the Commission are appointed because of their skilled qualifications as neutral officials, as guardians of the Treaty and as those who must convey the political visions of Parliament and the Council in a neutral way, then suffer The whole idea of a democratic European Union, which is why it is a shame that Jean-Claude Juncker will not come here today himself and stand on target for his appointment.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: — Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. What has happened here in recent weeks has made the European Union vulnerable. It makes itself vulnerable because, in the eyes of the public, it smells of nepotism, it smells like a promotion procedure at express speed. All this, Commissioner, may correspond to the letter of the rules, but in the eyes of the public this does not correspond to Europe's principles of transparency, openness and clear procedures with equal opportunities. And so: they recalled the candidate's political flair. I'm not going to question that, but I appeal to your political flair. Do not pretend that nothing has happened and everything is fine when basically many questions are rightly asked throughout Europe! Draw conclusions from this scandal, no longer use the derogations to the detriment of the transparency and openness of the procedure offered by the Staff Regulations. All positions — including here in Parliament, in the Commission — must be advertised openly and transparently. Such decisions are previously on the agenda of the bodies. Please take the consequences so that this will not be campaigning aid for populists in the European election campaign!

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: – Mr President, the facts really do point in a particular direction. The Commission has made a very senior appointment without following its own procedures adequately, certainly as far as transparency is concerned. This has flawed consequences. It demonstrates that checks and balances are, shall we say, missing from the work of the Commission. Equally that when it suits the Commission, it ignores the rules, meaning the rule of law. Following procedure is a necessary part of the rule of law. If the Commission is ready to ignore its own rules, why should anyone pay a blind bit of attention to what the Commission says about flaws in the rule of law in Member States or anywhere else for that matter?

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Commissioner Oettinger, your explanatory statement shows in particular what kind of bubble you actually live in. Outside, citizens ask themselves questions about this blitz appointment, and you come up with a dry explanation that does not answer any question. It's not about Martin Selmayr's person for me. No doubt he's brilliant. For me, it is about the way in which this appointment was orchestrated, the intrigue, the image of backroom and nepotism. It concerns the functioning of the Commission as a whole. It shows that collegiality in the Commission is pure semblance. It's about unhealthy concentration of power and influence. And it's about your communication. You have followed the rules, so to speak, religiously. Well, as a child, I have often listened to the parable of the Pharisee following the rules of Moses to the letter, but actually the paragon is of pride and arrogance. You often see the threats to the European Union elsewhere: in Russia with Putin, in America with Trump, in populism. But the real threat to the EU project, Commissioner, must be sought by yourself.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: — Mr President, Mr Oettinger, fraus omnia corrumpit, we learn on the benches of law schools, fraud corrupts everything. When you try to make this Parliament believe that the appointment of someone as deputy secretary-general for three minutes in order to escape the rules of external appointment and be appointed by the inner tower is a normal procedure for becoming secretary-general at the head of 33,000 people, I have no lesson to learn from you, Mr. Oettinger, no advice. None. You take us for fools, you lie. No independent authority, no independent authority, the one we defend, would agree to allow itself to be treated in this way. You should be ashamed! What you are doing for Europe, Mr Oettinger, and the whole of your Commission, is worse than all nationalists, extremists and Eurosceptics do. You are destroying the European project and European democracy.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Mr President! I have no doubt about Mr Selmayr's legal and scientific qualifications, but I have doubts about the procedure and its professional suitability as the superior of 33 000 officials. Mr Selmayr has so far only worked as a cabinet member of Luxembourg Commissioners, not as a German official — for those who wish to ascribe Germany. He lacks the experience in the normal career of civil servants, the promotion of parole: no head of department, no head of unit, no director — none of this. The procedure was anything but transparent — this is reminiscent of the secret buerocracy of the 19th century. And Mr Selmayr has often taken care of the other elected institutions in the past. He wanted to reiterate Mr Schulz as President of Parliament, who described four Commissioners in the Finnish press as unusable. Why he's still in office at all is surprising, ladies and gentlemen. But in the end I say: this is an inappropriate takeover of power in the EU, if you will, through the back door. Luxembourg has done it once again. This reminds me of the Augsburg doll box, where one pulls the strings upstairs and the dolls dance at the bottom.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: Mr President, Mr Oettinger, I think it is very clear for all the questions so far that your first speech was totally wrong. It was a formalistic answer in which it was pretended that everything had been followed according to the letter. But you also know: you have rules that you must follow according to the letter or that you must follow according to the spirit. And that is what it is about in this matter. It's about transparency. It's about credibility. It is about fair procedures, something that the Commission says it stands for. So, in your second answer, you can take revenge for your weak performance in the first phase. You will then be able to indicate where you think the rules need to be adapted so that next time we will not be able to experience such a flash procedure and an open, fair and transparent procedure will be followed, so that we can have confidence in the appointments of the officials of the European Union. Commission. That trust is incredibly important, and it is a pity that apparently you need some rules to stick to it. But it's up to you now to clarify where you feel that the procedure needs to be improved, otherwise you really will not be worth a cut for the nose.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Mr President, integrity is one of the most precious goods in politics. As a politician, you can still have as many qualities as you want, without integrity no one believes you and with those qualities you are ultimately nothing at all. And that is the case for the European institutions. And so we must take the lead all the more precisely when it comes to this integrity. I hope that today's debate shows this well. Apart from the objective qualities, there is another such thing as the way everything happens. That is why I would also ask the Commissioner to formally confirm here and now that not only the procedure has been followed correctly, but also that the rumors about the departure package of Commissioners, drivers and so on are completely wrong and therefore out of the air.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: — Madam President, at a time when the world is in full boil, when the United States is returning to its conservatism, its protectionism, when South Korea meets North Korea, when Putin and Russia are rearming, when Bashar al-Assad continues to intervene indiscriminately, at a time when Erdoğan continues to intervene indiscriminately with the Kurds, we here, what are we doing? We are talking about the inability of the President of the European Commission to respect the rules he himself has laid down, and I do not even want to talk about our President of the Parliamentary Assembly, who is practicing Corsican tango — Corsican tango is two steps forward and three steps back — since he told us just six months ago, “I will be speaker of a parliament and i will never be prime minister.” He had to be seduced by the Italian elections and proposed himself to serve as Prime Minister. The world laughs at us, parliamentary friends. Today, it is our responsibility to determine what role the European continent can play on an intercontinental scale instead of spending hours and hours debating issues that are not up to the global challenges we need to animate.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Madam President, Mr Oettinger, Mr Juncker should be here instead of you answering. And he had to be here to come and take responsibility, because when the matter came out, he said that it was his absolute right to appoint whoever he wishes as Secretary-General, because he compared himself in his statements with Mr Macron and Mrs Merkel and said that Just as they appoint whoever they want Secretary General, so can he at the Commission. So he had to come here, defend his views, defend his provocative illegal behaviour, because that's what he said in his statements. Now from the debate and from what you have said there are even more comments and more questions, because it is a fact that the chosen person became Deputy Secretary-General and immediately the next day Secretary-General. These are amazing things going on, but you shouldn't be here, Mr. Karen. Juncker to defend his choices.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Madam President, the European Commission's so-called 'integrity and transparency' policy can be summed up in this: the European Commission is fully at the service of the economic and financial interests which, at all times, determine its action and the content of its initiatives. And there is no more crystalline and transparent observation than this. The unconditional defence of these interests often requires the obscurity of procedures that no code of ethics or policy so-called “of transparency” can completely eliminate. This lack of integrity and transparency is not episodic, but rather something structural. As shocking as they may be, and are, some of the episodes that reveal this structural reality. But it is she, this reality that must be fought more than its episodic manifestation. Let it be the case with the former President of the European Commission and lobbyist of Goldman Sachs, who tries to influence Commissioners, or the now known expedient which, in due course, has put the all-powerful head of staff of the President of the European Commission to the top of the bureaucracy of the European Union.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, allow me to congratulate Mr Selmayr, a career politician in the mantle of a civil servant, on the achievement of double promotion in just a ten-minute period. Unfortunately, Parliament does not have the formal power to dismiss the Secretary-General of the Commission, who serves at the discretion of the College of Commissioners. But how hypocritical is the Commission's admonitions, when it attacks Member States with general declarations of the rule of law, when it does not even observe the pretext of ethics, transparency and meritocracy in its own house? The Commission's deficit of integrity is already known. It manifests itself in practices that respect the letter but not the spirit of the regulations: the different interpretation and application of the same rules to the Member States as they see fit, the undisguised politicisation of the administration of theoretically neutral bodies and mechanisms and the German-occupied staffing key positions. In this Union there are no accomplices, but only responsible, there is no room for conciliation or acceptance and, if necessary, I will support a proposal to dispose of the appointed Commission.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, Commissioners, there are those days when I am ashamed to be a Member of the European Parliament. And I must say that this is such a day, and it is not because I think that we — our support services or the Commission services — are not doing a very useful job to deal with issues that are of interest to European citizens in a proper way. But when I look at the image of Europe, the image of Europe today is: Europe is out of the back rooms, of unclear appointments. And there is also a whole question of shady promises to Commissioners above the table without it being discussed here in Parliament today. So I am glad that there will be an investigation, because I would like to feel proud of the work I am doing here and not be ashamed of the European Parliament.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: — Mr President, there have been strong arguments that the Commission's important appointment of office did not go in accordance with the rules. The most important thing for the European taxpayer is that the best of the applicants are always selected for all official positions, without discrimination, without any preference. The least the Commission can do in this situation is to tell the truth about how this appointment has been concluded, whether and how the case could be remedied. Political office appointments are corruption. Is this the direction the Commission wants to develop the European Union?

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, the appointment of Mr Selmayr, a political friend of Mr Juncker, as Secretary-General of the European Commission, who was unannounced and openly, is nothing more than a coup in the operation of this institution. Twenty-eight Commissioners were bypassed, who became mere spectators of events and paradoxically did not react, obviously in order to gain personal benefits. The States have also been circumvented, from which the opportunity to intervene has been removed. This whole approach has been made for one obvious reason: the small leadership circle of the European Union wants to appoint people in all the institutions whom it controls completely, in order to manipulate the process and decisions of these institutions. It is clear that the European Union has escaped from the principles and values on which it was founded, has become an instrument for meeting the aims of globalisation, and that is why it is choosing puppets to do what they must do. This situation will change very quickly, because in the next European elections the Member States will send patriots to this area and corrupt politicians will enter the timeliness of history.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Madam President, at the last plenary we were dealing with Mr Barroso, former Commissioner, now working for Goldman Sachs, coming back to bribe, perhaps, or perhaps just influence the present Commission. At this plenary we are talking about a political appointee becoming the Secretary-General of the European Commission, in violation of all the relevant rules. In the meantime, the same European Union dares to have Article 7 proceedings against my country, Hungary, and against Poland for violation of the rule of law. Don’t you think that you should immediately, after this very session, stop these Article 7 proceedings and start proceedings instead against yourselves?

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. — (DE) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. Please remove from me that I have a great deal of respect for the Commission, but also personally, for the importance of Parliament, not arrogant here, do not want to treat you as young children, take your questions seriously and also look forward to the investigation with great seriousness and serenity. Let us pay mutual respect. Secondly, fraud, corruption, scandal, intrigue, personal benefits: this has been assued by some speakers. That is why, I have the utmost interest in an objective investigation in and through the Committee on Budgetary Control. All questions will be answered there. Questions received in writing by 5 March — the date of the postmark — will be answered within the deadline of 14 March, separate from today's relatively short consultation period. Why am I here? Because that is exactly what the Conference of Presidents decided. It was your high house, it was your president, it was your group chairmen who, disagreeing on the ECR and the GUE, said by a large majority 'Oettingers Portfolio', so the Oettinger has to come here. That's why I'm here. I am sure that if the Conference of Presidents wanted to speak to my President, he would be present. This means that I am here because the Conference of Presidents, your conference in preparation, expected this from the Commission. We meet your expectations. Secretary General Martin Selmayr spoke as a grey bureaucrat. This German Selmayr — no one knows him. I'm quoting! My request is that discrimination is not acceptable in Europe. Officials should not be discriminated against in any way. If a monster is written in the press, it's up to the free press. But I think every official, small or large official, has enough Worthy care and respect from all of us. It is said that the Germans will once again dominate Europe with this decision. I often hear the following in Germany: why is each Member State represented by a Commissioner? Why do even the smallest Member States like the big ones have a Commissioner? I think it's right. I believe that every Member State should be represented on an equal footing in the Court of Justice, in the Court of Auditors, in the Commission. But please take it from me: in the large Member States it is already being asked why only one in 28 or that in this House the small Member States have a Member of Parliament representing 90 thousand inhabitants, while in the large Member States one Member has nine hundred thousand inhabitants. One man, one vote. Nevertheless, I think it is right that Malta and Luxembourg are represented by six Members. But I would like to make it clear here that we are all on the issue of fair representation of our Member States, of nationality... (interrogation) I also listened to you, Madam President. If you want to ask a question, please. Otherwise, I would ask you to give your questions in an orderly and comprehensive manner... I come to all the questions, Madam. It's been 20 questions. You'll also notice that I'm trying to answer your questions. One after another, patience and respect. The question of nationality is completely secondary to me. I feel like a European citizen who is one of 28 in the Commission. I believe that this is why the question of where you were born and the passport date should be of less importance. It has been said that the Commission was not elected. I strongly disagree with that. A candidate for Commissioner is proposed by his democratically elected government. He is grilled by this high house on the expert committee. He is chosen by this House. It is elected by the European Council. I know many member states where you can will become a national minister without the national parliament being involved at all. If, for example, the chancellor is elected in Germany in two days' time — the ministers will be appointed by the parties and confirmed by the President. No choice, no hearing, nothing — as in the European Parliament, for example. That is why I maintain that the Commission complies with democratic principles more than many other bodies at national level. I can tell you that this Commission had no intention and does not intend to organise company cars, drivers and offices for all Commissioners after leaving the Commission. I think this is fake news. We have set it out on several occasions, and I can assure you here that, under my responsibility, there is no proposal to change anything about this subject with regard to all the Commissioners after their departure. It has been said by some Members that the rules according to the letter may have been respected. First of all, letters are the basis for keeping rules. That is why I look forward to the reviews. We fully complied with all the rules after the letter. This is doubted by some. Let's check that. I am very happy to answer your questions here. But this statute on how to carry out promotions, appointments in the Commission, is not a presidential statute. The Statute on the basis of which Martin Selmayr was appointed Secretary-General is a statute adopted by this House and the Council. It's your statute, it's your letters, it's your rules. If you want to change them, we need to talk about it. Sorry, the staff regulations and what the Council has decided have emerged in the democratic bodies of the Council and Parliament! This can be changed. But these appointments do not happen after arbitrariness of the Commission, but on the basis of the following points: and also in the spirit of what has been decided and decided in the European democratic fora. We have three options for deciding on the filling of positions and appointing them: the internal tender, the external tender and the transfer within the service. All three — internal call for tenders, external tendering and transfer — are provided for in our Articles of Association. Officer Martin Selmayr was Head of Cabinet of our President for three years. And this is exactly what, Head of Cabinet, corresponds to the level of Directors-General, while head of cabinet of a commissioner corresponds to the level of directors. That is why, over the past three years, he has carried out and fulfilled with your knowledge a task that will enable him to take up the post of Secretary General in accordance with the method we have used. We should not build a distorted picture of Mr Selmayr either. He's not a party man, nor is he a monster, nor is he incapable. That is why my request is to give him a chance in the task execution in the next few months with your strict eye! I am sure he will perform the task excellently, and this as someone who is a service provider to President Juncker and to the Commission. I don't think distorting images are appropriate here in any form. If you don't like him, if you don't trust him, say it! But no one here has given this House a negative opinion on his qualifications and work skills and his various positions in recent years. We will gladly address ourselves to the Committee on Budgetary Control and will also answer written questions. I myself am also ready to come to any of your bodies, to your group meetings, including the bilateral talks, and I will be happy to take some time to answer all your concerns and questions in the coming weeks through clear answers with regard to the European Statute and the law on the European Statute. satisfaction of all questioners.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – To everyone’s surprise, the EU’s executive body has turned the replacement of its Secretary-General into an absolute fiasco. The recent coup d’Etat or the so-called “selection” process, is another shameful example of bending the rules and ignoring norms. This “Blitzkrieg” method of appointing Mr. Selmayr, who orchestrated his own selection procedure, the legitimacy of which is questionable at best, is a little reminiscent of the case of former Commissioner Kallas. The latter was himself at the source of a set of transparency rules, which led to the creation of the transparency register, but a couple of months after his term as a Commissioner, he simultaneously held positions as special advisor to the Commissioner Dombrovskis and consultant at a private-sector software company Nortal, without having himself or Nortal registered in the transparency register. These, and many other Commission’s gimmicks, where they claimed having done things “by the book”, are becoming increasingly detrimental to the integrity of the EU institutions and will be scrutinised in the Parliament’s CONT Committee. But this should not remain the standard, as I call for the College of Commissioners to take collective responsibility for such administrative calamities as the abovementioned affairs.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Eleonora Forenza and Malin Björk, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade and the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, on Gender Equality in EU Trade Agreements (2017/2015 (INI)) (A8-0023/2018)

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to thank first of all my parliamentary group colleague Malin Björk, Azadeh Jafari and Roberta Paoletti. This report is the result of a relationship between women and I hope that this will also emerge from the text. I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, the staff of the Secretariat of the Committee, who contributed to the drafting of this report, the NGOs and the experts involved in the hearing, in particular the AIDOS association and the Stop TTIP Italia network, for the contribution they have made. I would also like to thank very much the Feminist collective Nine, whose manifesto commits me to try to make a difference in this institution as well, and the worldwide feminist movement Not One Less, dropped in the square also last March 8th, for the strength it gives to everyone and to each, including myself. When this parliamentary term began, a report we commissioned to the Committee on International Trade called the EU's trade policy “gender-blind”, and gave us some indications on how to make her “gender-sensitive”. In the report I was rapporteur in 2016 — report on social and environmental norms, human rights and corporate responsibility and their impact in international trade policies — we were already trying to call for a reversal of the Union's trade policy, a reversal of course that would make human rights clauses binding, and not subject to those clauses which instead protect the profit and rights of investors. In that report, we called for human, social and environmental rights to be defined not simply non-tariff barriers, but precisely central elements, which should also be safeguarded in trade policy. In this report we are concerned with those basic human rights which are women's rights. Gender equality is an expected universal goal by international instruments and also the fundamental treaties of the European Union, which should commit itself to promoting and ensuring gender equality in its political actions, and therefore also in politics commercial. I would recall that among the broader objectives of the United Nations, the Sustainable Development Goals, and in particular Objective 5, stipulate that gender equality, the emancipation of women and girls must be reached by 2030. None of this is yet fully present in the EU's trade policy, and this report is speaking in this direction. According to estimates, only 20% of trade agreements mention women's rights, while the European Union is ratifying negotiations or negotiating treaties including services, and therefore more than previous trade agreements are intertwined with human rights and women's rights. I come to some of the main points of this report, which has not been difficult to lay down, given the different political souls that have worked to find a summary. The points, I am sure, will be explained in more detail by my colleague Malin Björk; what I want to say, however, very rightly at the conclusion of this speech, is that I hope that this can be a To change from a feminist point of view — which is a point of view that calls for justice, not only for women and girls, but for all — the trade policy of the European Union, which cannot be governed solely by the logic of competition and profit.

name: Malin BJÖRK
