text: rapporteur. — Madam President! From the left, we want trade policy to contribute to a more equitable distribution of the world's resources and wealth. We want it to help stop climate change, to strengthening democracy — and all that we are working on. But with this report we wanted to focus on the situation of women and on gender equality. International trade policy is an important part of our economic policy. It is an important part of our foreign policy. Trade policy concerns fundamental issues of democracy, human rights, workers' rights, issues of consumer safety, public health issues, basic climate and environment provisions. All these parts also touch on gender equality and the situation of women. Trade policy is not gender neutral. Women are affected differently than men depending on their position in the economy, depending on whether it is an export-oriented economy, whether it is a more agriculture-oriented economy, depending on the state of employment, etc. We address all this in our report. We believe that there is no longer enough slogans such as that we should export democracy or we should export equality, human rights or sustainable development or any of the areas that we care so much about. We need to formulate tools and have steering instruments so that it becomes a reality of what we say as well and so that our negotiators focus on the right things and know what expectations we have of them. International trade policy has rested a little bit on a premeditated view, which means that all the demands of the environment and human rights or equality have received the answer that 'yea, they don't belong here, you get them fixed elsewhere with some other tools or in another negotiation'. We mean that time must be up. Trade policy is an exclusive competence that Member States have given to the EU. Therefore, it is extra important and reasonable that we discuss and review and set up frameworks for how we wants future agreements to look like. In this effort we have had tremendous support from civil society, women's organisations and MRI organisations. We've gained expertise, and we've had deliberations and hearings. I would like to thank my co-rapporteur Mr Eleonora Forenza, but also my shadow rapporteurs. We have had different centres of gravity and partly different entrances, but those who took on this mission from their respective groups were clearly the ones most interested in seeing and analysing the impact on women and formulating constructive criticism and suggestions. For that, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs. I am not going to go through all the individual elements of the report, but I would like to highlight some of the most important elements. As Forenza has said, we want to see a gender equality chapter with the objectives of women's rights and on women's economic empowerment — objectives that must be based on the Beijing platform that is supposed to have equality experts and civil society involved in its follow-up, and we shall have a review of compliance with this chapter. We also want the EU's trade policy to combat exploitation and aim to improve working conditions for women in the export industry, whether in agriculture, textile industry or elsewhere. We believe that ILO standards and UN sustainability goals are central to this. We also believe that there should be binding provisions on respect for human rights, democracy, working conditions and the environment. Trade policy must not undermine access to public services, education, health, including sexual and reproductive health and rights. We also believe that the UN Women's Convention SIDO should be part of the trade agreements and that the EU itself should join. We want to see due diligence in a real way for businesses. As I said, I would like to thank my co-rapporteur, my colleagues and the shadow rapporteurs. Here, then, are some of the things our report calls for if we want EU trade policy to live up to both global needs and expectations. I now look forward to the Commission moving from word to action, including in terms of gender equality in trade policy.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me first thank Parliament, the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM) and the Committee on International Trade (INTA), and, of course, the co-rapporteurs Ms Malin Björk and Ms Eleonora Forenza, for the attention, the work and the time that they have invested in this report on Gender Equality in EU Trade Agreements. It makes a very valuable contribution to strengthening gender aspects in EU trade policy. The Commission is committed to gender equality. EU trade policy already contributes to this goal through some of its instruments, for example, its sustainability impact assessments, the Generalised System of Preferences, the GSP+ and the Trade and Sustainable Development Chapters of the European Union’s free trade agreements. However, we need to do more.  To gather input from stakeholders, in June last year the Commission and the International Trade Centre organised an International Forum on Women and Trade, to which the honourable Members Mosca, Rodríguez-Piñero and Forenza kindly contributed as speakers. The Commission has already put some of the ideas that emerged from this event into practice, and I can assure you that we will continue to do so.  The report identifies a lack of adequate data on trade and gender equality when it comes to determining the impact of trade policy instruments on women. In cooperation with other international organisations, for example the World Trade Organisation (WTO), the International Trade Centre, United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), the OECD or the European Institutes for Gender Equality, we are exploring how to better collect and use data on the impact of trade policy instruments on women. We are also looking to improve our analysis by using the most advanced methods, like the UNCTAD toolbox on trade and gender. Following a suggestion from this House, the Commission and the International Trade Centre are also launching a collection of firm level data on women entrepreneurship and female employment in EU-exporting and importing firms.  Let me mention some further activities to contribute to the promotion of women’s economic empowerment: the European Union’s recently reviewed Aid for Trade strategy introduces, for all its projects, the requirement of a systematic gender analysis. We are currently working with Chile on gender-specific provisions in the context of modernisation of the existing EU-Chile Association Agreement. These provisions will include commitments to effectively implement relevant international legal instruments on gender equality, such as the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women and a structured framework for cooperating and sharing best practices on women in international trade. The Commission will keep the INTA Committee informed about the development of the EU proposals for these provisions on trade and gender. In the international arena, the EU actively supported the adoption of the Joint Declaration on Trade and Women’s Economic Empowerment on the occasion of the WTO Ministerial Conference in Buenos Aires in December 2017. The Declaration seeks to remove barriers to and foster women’s economic empowerment. We now need to move ahead with implementation. The Commission is ready to sponsor several follow-up actions, such as organising workshops, collecting data on women’s participation in international trade, and applying a gender lens to our trade-related technical assistance. Finally, the Commission uses every opportunity to raise awareness of the importance of gender equality for economic growth and the opportunities that trade can provide, including through trade policy reviews in the WTO. Last but not least, the EU’s commitment towards gender equality and women’s empowerment has been expanded by the EU Gender Action Plan too, placing gender at the heart of the European Union’s actions, from international relations to commercial agreements, and holding all of us accountable for its achievements. I look forward to hearing your views.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development — Madam President, new-generation trade treaties, such as the EU-Mexico agreement, strengthen corporate power, perpetuate inequalities, the wage gap between men and women and human rights violations, through grabbing natural resources. Equality clauses only make up the obvious incompatibility between these types of treaties and respect for life. How does the Commission intend to ensure gender equality? Will trade agreements require the extension of paid, non-transferable maternity and paternity times and guarantee return to work? Will they force the wage gap to be banned and penalized? Would the privatization of public services be prohibited so that care was the responsibility of the State and did not systematically fall on women? Will they guarantee free access to nursery centers and nursery schools? And are they going to prohibit trafficking in women and persecute those who pay for prostitution? The millions of women who backed the feminist strike this past March 8 demand from us political changes, not just words. And that is our mandate.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteurs for the work that has been done. Equality between men and women is one of Europe's values and we must use all the tools at our disposal to promote it, including our trade policy. International trade has varying consequences for men and women, and it is fundamental that it benefits all equally. Gender equality needs to be taken more into account in EU trade policy, as soon as impact assessments are carried out, and data must be collected on this subject. On the other hand, the instruments at our disposal, such as the generalized system of preferences or the sustainable development chapters of agreements, must better integrate gender equality and we must ensure their full and effective implementation. Furthermore, I welcome the initiative of the European Commission to include, for the first time, a specific chapter on this subject in the modernisation of the agreement with Chile. It is essential that our trade policy contributes to combating the exploitation of women, improving their working conditions and strengthening corporate social responsibility. In line with the WTO declaration on the role of women in trade and a few days after International Women's Rights Day, I am pleased that Parliament is sending a strong message on this subject.

name: Maria NOICHL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (DE) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. Trade must serve the people. Trade makes sense at all only if it serves people; it has no other purpose. Trade has no end in itself. It has been seen in recent weeks and months that the issue of 'EU trade, trade agreements' has driven people onto the streets, all over Europe. After all, people were no longer sure: does trade serve them at all, or should they only serve trade? I believe that these fundamental things are at stake. We only have one minute, so I would like to confine myself to five principles. Firstly, it is time, and it is high time that women were finally in the focus of trade agreements. Secondly, women's rights are never barriers to trade, must never be barriers to trade. Thirdly, women's rights create prosperity in all countries. Fourthly, women belong to the negotiating table when it comes to agreements. Fifth, women are part of the team that controls the agreements on a daily basis. Women are a part of humanity, are half of humanity. In future, therefore, trade will not have to serve people, but trade will have to serve women and men alike in the future. That is our goal.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group — Madam President, my view is that the European Union and the whole of Europe are facing a demographic winter. Every country of the European Union lacks children who are our future. There are no children, because people often selfishly choose a comfortable life without worries or those children were killed before they were born on behalf of sexual and reproductive rights. Abortions make Europe have a future at risk. Nor is there any mention in this document of the need to support families with children. By giving birth to children, the development of our society will also be ensured in the future. But often it is customary in European Union legislation that this report deals with allowing a woman to enter the labour process as soon as possible, regardless of what she wants and what her family needs. If a woman wants to stay home and take care of our future, that is, the next generation of children, she faces prejudice. A woman caring for children or other family member is often discriminated against and faces poverty. If she remains in a blessed state and is without the support of her husband or partner, abortion is a terrible way out for her. I think that this philosophy does not work in Europe, it brings us great problems, and it has to be said: Europe is dying. With this report, I think we want to export the culture of death to third countries through trade treaties. And so today, countries with enough children will face problems similar to us in Europe in a few years. This is a modern colonisation, and third world countries should not accede to this, because it will not bring them economic development.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, we Liberals know well that free trade is a very powerful engine of progress, thanks to which hundreds of millions of people have emerged from poverty. Women can be the major beneficiaries of trade, as long as they have the power and protection necessary for their talent. Europe does business with countries like Iran or Saudi Arabia, where women live in a semi-slavery regime. Only 20 per cent of EU trade agreements refer to women's rights. Henceforth, I call for all agreements signed to incorporate binding and enforceable provisions in this regard. It is very significant that the current enemies of trade, from Trump to Wilders, are also enemies of gender equality. Reactionaries always try to preserve certain privileges. That is why the best weapons we have against them and in favour of progress are precisely trade and equality.

name: Margot PARKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, 12 million women in the EU have jobs that depend on the export of goods and services to the rest of the world. Whilst trade can liberate the poorest of nations, it is of paramount importance that women are protected by labour laws avoiding issues with precarious work, and that discrimination be eradicated, and that there are equal opportunities for men and women. Promotion of free trade empowers people to be economically active, lifting people out of poverty, boosting education and creating higher standards of living. But I believe gender equality should be brought about by cultural change with voices of both men and women. Incorporating gender mainstreaming into policy is not the answer. Therefore, it is an absolute priority that during the negotiations with the UK, the EU be fair. At the expense of stubbornness and bitterness at the UK’s exit, and fear of other EU countries following suit, the EU could risk jeopardising the livelihood of those women and men whose jobs are reliant upon trade. It is a clear case where politics from any source cannot be allowed to interfere with good sense and the wellbeing of women everywhere.

name: France JAMET
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, at a time when President Trump is introducing protectionist measures on steel and aluminium, at a time when there is agreement that free trade agreements are harmful to our livestock, agricultural, sugar and the health of our fellow citizens, you introduce us, dear colleagues, like the Byzantine religious who were still discussing the sex of angels when Turkish forces were preparing to bring down Constantinople, a report on gender equality in trade agreements, in a Europe with nearly twenty million unemployed, a Europe with a negative trade balance and where our traditions and our environment are under threat. Colleagues, moreover, in this report there are common sense measures and a lucid assessment of the consequences, particularly in free trade agreements and trade relations in general. So, if we agree to denounce the risks of globalism, its social and economic violence, let us defend with the same energy our sectors, our traditions, our environment, consumers and consumers.

name: Godelieve QUISTHOUDT-ROWOHL
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I believe that a value-based trade policy is very relevant with the aim of creating a high level of protection for labour, environmental and human rights with a view to sustainable global development, and I support appropriate measures. It is important that these measures, including the establishment of women's rights, do not overload free trade agreements and unduly restrict the international trade in goods and services. International trade worldwide, with a few exceptions, contributes to increasing prosperity, in particular to job creation and to improving wage and working conditions. This also applies to women. However, binding chapters, even linked to sanctions, are counterproductive. On balance, this would do more harm than benefit. That is why the EPP would not support this.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: Madam President, first of all I congratulate the rapporteurs on their excellent work, the consensus reached and for taking up the content of the 56 amendments which I tabled on behalf of the Group of Socialists and Democrats. Thanks to the Commissioner, and also to Commissioner Malmström, for her commitment to the gender perspective in trade policy, which is essential to move forward but still very insufficient. Let us not forget that the number of years needed to achieve parity continues to grow and is already 52 years old. Women are half the population, but we represent more than 70 per cent of the world's 1 billion poorest people. The world's employed population is 72 per cent for men, compared with 47 per cent for women, who enter only 77 per cent of men's wages and are mostly active in the informal economy. But closing the gender gap is also an issue of economic efficiency, as it would increase global GDP if parity was reached by up to 10 trillion euros. No policy can fight inequality in isolation and change the face of women to poverty, but I am firmly convinced that much can be done in international trade. That is why I call on the Commission to support the measures envisaged in this report, which is widely supported by this Parliament, and among which I highlight the following: the inclusion of a gender chapter in all trade agreements, also where they are now being negotiated, as well as ambitious sustainable development chapters, with effective and enforceable mandatory measures in the area of labor rights and labor and environmental standards, taking care of course to women's rights and freedoms. Gender impact assessments are necessary and experts need to be incorporated into negotiation processes throughout the negotiation process. And it is it is also essential to work to ensure that the gender perspective in trade agreements is a global cause and therefore to engage the World Trade Organization. Only from the commitment and involvement of all will we ensure that the gender perspective acquires the prominence it needs.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Madam President! International trade takes place without regard to the person's reputation, it depends on the purchasing power of the person concerned. Discrimination against women cannot be identified in any trade agreement — why! Of course, if women have purchasing power, they will also appear as buyers. Gender blindness has been mentioned here. That's it! Sure, contracts are genderblind, they do not pay attention to the person. And when it is said: not competition and profit — yeah, what else? Discrimination and losses? One example has been given: international trade is damaging the agricultural economy in Africa, especially women who appear as farmers there. Why is that? Because we have a failed agricultural policy and we export the surpluses of this agricultural policy to Africa! That's why the farmers perish. Furthermore, what is being presented here is not a text on external trade, but external trade is used as a lever to assert its own European interests. This is, so to speak, from a position of power. If we were a small country, the whole world would laugh at us if we made such demands. But we have 500 million consumers behind us. That is why we can try to assert our view of genderism in the world. This is arrogance, this is striving for power!

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteurs for this report, which brings together, as it turns out, the non-obvious links between trade and equality. Trade agreements contribute to the economic development of the world and therefore greater job opportunities for women and improve the situation of their households. But you have to remember that especially in developing countries, women are often used for almost slave labor, at very low rates. The European Union should not agree to this. Trade agreements provide opportunities to put pressure on the parties so that they respect human rights and workers' rights. The European Union has a duty to promote the idea of equality in trade agreements as well as to reduce the exploitation of women at work and improve their chances of good education and work, thereby helping to improve their lives and develop the economies of the countries in which they live. I also share the intentions expressed in section 29 of the report, which calls on the European Investment Bank to control whether companies participating in investment projects comply with the principles of equality policy.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President! Women's rights are not respected — especially in terms of equality — even in some Member States of the European Union, and indeed only in third countries. Very bad, tragically, dramatically it looks very common in undeveloped countries and developing states. Women there very often are, for example, employed unlawfully, especially in agriculture, but also in industry. Therefore, all possible instruments should be taken to promote women's rights and equality between men and women. However, in terms of trade agreements, it is necessary to act prudently and responsibly. For trade agreements, not as said here, do not serve only profits, and only economics, but also social development. I believe that if it were not for trade agreements and the cooperation of the European Union with third countries, the situation for women would be even worse in these countries. Therefore, I would appeal a little to lower the temperature of the discussion.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are debating a resolution highlighting the potential that trade agreements can represent for women working and entrepreneurs. A European Commission study shows that increased participation by women in the real economy could boost global GDP by $25 billion by 2025. A staggering figure, which would add to the benefits of globalisation in terms of eradicating poverty and emancipation of women. Important elements which, as stated in the text of the report, must not and cannot be irrespective of respect for human rights, which remain central to trade relations. Europe is the world's leading exporter of goods and services: an immense bargaining power which the Union must continue to use as a lever for the protection of women's rights, but not forgetting European business interests. However, we must not fall into the temptation to rise to the chair and demand that our trading partners reach our high standards of protection of rights fast. I believe in dialogue and the exchange of good practice.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Colleagues and colleagues, trade agreements should lead to the objectives of the European Union and, of course, to respect the values of the European Union. The promotion of economic interests must not take place at the cost of retreating from the European values to which the European Union subscribes. One of those values is precisely the protection of human rights and the dignity of human life. It is a sad reality that women have a weaker position in certain sectors than men, and trade agreements could just have a negative impact in these cases. Therefore, I consider it right that the Commission also assess the impact on women's status as part of the impact assessment. I appreciate the appointment of a liaison for gender issues within the Directorate-General for Trade and would also welcome the greater involvement of women in the negotiating processes. I believe that it is right that certain topics such as sexual and reproductive health remain a matter for the Member States and I reject any speculation about the impact of the European trade policy union on the sexual and reproductive health of women.

name: Maria ARENA
text: — Madam President, Mrs Thyssen, I prefer you when you talk about employment than when you talk about trade. It is true that today there are — and Mrs Malmström said so — winners and losers of globalisation and there are winners and losers of globalisation. The objective of this report is to ensure that there are more winners and fewer losers of globalization. There is an important tool that can be implemented, namely the chapter on sustainable development, which also provides for the implementation of sanctions. Today there is a chapter “sustainable development”. It does not work within the framework of trade agreements and we therefore advocate the introduction of a mandatory chapter with sanctions to ensure that those who do not comply with them are effectively sanctioned. So we will have a lot of agreements on the table, agreements that are negotiated, agreements that are going to be voted on. Therefore, it is time to take action, even though I know that today the European Commission — as well as the EPP, indeed — does not want to hear about sanctions, but then these are purely and simply beautiful words that will never achieve their objectives.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Madam President, the various trade agreements of the European Union lead to the opening up of markets, and we have seen that in practice what they are doing is dismantling small and medium-sized enterprises in the European Union, because the countries with which the European Union has concluded agreements are countries that do not comply with labour law, secondly, have starvation wages, do not comply with environmental standards and in practice lead to unfair competition and thus dismantle European economies. All the more so, the most affected are women, who are the most vulnerable part of the economy in the European Union. See also what is happening: in developing countries they do not respect equal pay for equal work, so they have women who work excellently, while of course they are not paid on equal terms with men and thus create additional unfair competition. Measures are needed to support women in the European Union's trade agreements as well.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs and I want to break a spear here for Commissioner Malmström's attitude, capacity and willingness to incorporate the gender vision into European Union trade agreements. This is a good tool for extending the equality movement across the globe and I believe that equality is a fundamental rights issue and they are all interrelated. And I also believe that taking into account the role of women's work in sectors such as agriculture or services is an obligation and an exercise of coherence with the development cooperation policies that we are also supporting. As a result, many local communities in the southern countries have begun to become socially and economically viable, but they are still fragile spaces that need the support of a fair trade relations system that takes these circumstances into account. We cannot afford to break this flame of hope, which is also the key to solving many other problems.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, trade agreements are particularly harmful to women all over the world. The introduction of these trade agreements in the North and South means that products are placed on the markets at a price below production costs, they relocate production, expel women from local and local markets - for example in agriculture - and create unemployment and very high working conditions precarious, for example in the textile sector. If the European Union wants to minimise gender impacts, it must end the trade agreements made by and for multinationals and guarantee the right to food sovereignty of peoples and prevent all forms of dumping. Commissioner, the women's strike on 8 March reinforces the need for concrete measures on the part of public administrations.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: Madam President, this 8 March has been historic: women from all over the world have taken to the streets to denounce the inequality and violence to which they are subjected daily. This inequality and discrimination are also present in trade treaties. Women are underrepresented in negotiation processes. In many cases trade agreements increase women's precarious work, and we negotiate trade agreements with countries like Saudi Arabia, where women's rights are lacking. However, women's economic empowerment is one of the objectives of sustainable development to which the European Union has acceded. We therefore call for gender impact assessments on each trade treaty. We also welcome the fact that the European Commission has proposed a chapter on gender equality in the trade agreement with Chile and we call for this to become a standard and binding practice from now on.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I wanted to make a point and speak as a woman who has been in the chamber listening to the whole debate. Sexism is a system of oppression that affects every aspect of life. It must be tackled at every level of decision-making and in every sector. Unfortunately, in many cases, the fight for gender equality and trade agreements is disregarded or left out in favour of other interests. I am happy that this report on EU trade insists on the importance of adopting a gendered approach. Trade includes a wide variety of issues and sectors, which affect women and LGBTIQ+ people. It is absolutely crucial to properly assess the impact our commercial policy has on gender equality. I would like to thank the rapporteurs for stating that the EU’s trading commitments should never overrule human rights. This must always be our first priority. Unfortunately, the Conservative Government’s chasing of post-Brexit trade agreements at any cost will mean that human rights, gender equality and social justice will be sacrificed on the altar of neo-liberal values. Therefore, it’s time to stop Brexit and continue the collective fight for a fairer world.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: — Madam President, congratulations to rapporteurs Björk and Forenza on their feminist commitment. The lack of protection of human rights, and in particular equality, is a classic of the privatizing and solidarity European trade agreements. Women and girls are vulnerable groups, discriminated against, excluded, absent from political decisions - political decisions such as those that led to the feminist strike on our streets on March 8. This strike, which is already a symbol, Commissioner, of the need for another possible world for women in Europe and in the world at large. We want changes on the road with binding human clauses. That is why I want to remember today the women in the textile sector of Rana Plaza, and also the Mapuche women, excluded so far from the agreements with Chile.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would again like to thank honourable Members for their interest, questions and suggestions. I would like to assure Members that the Commission will take their observations and recommendations into consideration in its future work on trade and women’s economic empowerment. As the report recognises, there are limits to the extent to which global issues can be solved through trade policy and free trade agreements alone. Domestic policies, such as those tackling gender segregation in the labour market and alleviating the disproportionate care responsibilities that women face, are clearly the key. However, we must all do our share.  Therefore, the Commission will continue to make the European Union’s trade policy more inclusive so that it contributes to women’s economic empowerment. I promise you, also in the name of my colleague, Ms Malmström, who – as you know – is a female Commissioner for Trade, that the Commission will keep you closely informed on developments, including the trade negotiations with Chile on trade and gender provisions.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the Commissioner and thank those who have spoken or spoke in this debate, which I believe has highlighted the attempt to bring a feminist point of view, therefore of social justice, for all and all, within the trade policy of the European Union, calling for a change of course, using the intersectional and cross-sectional elaboration of the movement feminist who, in fact, took to the streets once again on March 8. We strongly demand that this view be inserted not as an element of maquillage, speech and rhetorical ornament within the trade policy negotiations, but that there be a substantial change. I shall appoint here some of the points that will be consolidated if this report, as I hope, is adopted tomorrow. A gender chapter on the model of the mandate that was given to the Commission for the Renegotiation and Modernization of the Treaty with Chile — mentioned earlier by Mrs Rodríguez-Piñero, who was rapporteur of that Parliament report, and shadow rapporteur for this report, which I thank. As Mrs Arena mentioned, we ask that there be binding and sanctionable elements in the clauses defending human rights and gender equality; that public services be taken from commercial and non-privatised treaties; that there are dispute settlement mechanisms that ensure the ability of individual governments to legislate in defence of the public interest and in the service of public policy objectives; that there is an urgency with regard to the CEDAW Convention — we will shortly discuss in this Chamber of the Istanbul Convention — that the European Parliament is constantly coming informed of all negotiation steps; that there are ex post and ex ante assessments with regard to gender differentiated impacts; that there is a gender point of view not only to end of trading, but during trading. I hope, and I really hope, that Parliament will be able to approve this report: it would be a nice response to the demonstrations on 8 March.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I must start by thanking my co-rapporteur, the shadow rapporteurs, my colleagues Azadeh Jafari and Roberta Paoletti, and WIDE, an organisation working with the global south and in the EU for women’s rights and which has provided expertise for us in this work. I think some of my colleagues here have said what this report actually started with: the question of trade for whom and for what? And the answer coming back is that it is not neutral. It is certainly not neutral when it comes to women. We took it upon ourselves to formulate some of the principles, and it is true that trade polices cannot fix everything, but it cannot be free-floating, from human rights, from women’s rights, from environmental rights and public health. The bottom line has been said here over and over again, there has to be some stepping-up of the work, there has to be some binding measures. I think our report outlines some of the key elements of that. I hear from the Commission that you welcome our report, and that is very nice, I also hear about the toolbox, the data collection, the women entrepreneurs, all important things, but I am missing the commitment that we will take this on board – the gender chapter, the binding things, the references to CEDAW, to the SDGs, etc. So we look forward to Ms Malmström, and you and the Commission, coming back and discussing these things with us. I hope and I expect the Commission to take this on board because it also means a lot in who we are as a player on the global level. These are actions that we see for the EU as a trade partner itself, but also who we are when we negotiate global trade deals and trade policies, be it at WTO or UN level. We have to look ourselves in the eye. Nobody else is going to take gender equality further, as well as social rights, in EU trade deals if we don’t do it. So I think as some of my colleagues have said, it is time to pass to action, passer à l’action.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: - The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 13 March 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. – Our society is struggling with many unconscious biases and discriminatory norms and attitudes, in many aspects of our lives, in employment, and especially in the media sector. Our failure to address gender inequality. We need to devote resources for training, and awareness-raising campaigns to promote egalitarian practices and values. Action is essential to ensure that existing rules on equal treatment in employment are enforced. We must foster a cultural atmosphere in which women feel better supported to disclose their experiences, so that harassment and discrimination cases are not left unreported; harassment policies need to be clearly outlined and reach the highest possible standards of fairness, clarity, and transparency.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: in writing. — Equality between women and men has not been achieved in any country. Women and men continue to have different social status. Women are sparse in many decision-maker seats. If women and girls are not at the negotiating tables to participate in decision-making, there is a risk of not understanding how the effects of decisions on women and men differ. The EU should show leadership in respect of gender equality and high levels of protection of fundamental rights and environmental rights of workers in trade policy. All EU trade agreements must have an ambitious and viable chapter on trade and sustainable development. This is in line with the EU Treaty that “in all its actions, the Union will seek to eliminate inequality between men and women and promote equality between men and women.”

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. — — This resolution on gender equality in EU trade agreements marks the European Parliament's determination to modernise and rethink its trade policies by ensuring that everyone has the means of livelihood, protecting the environment and ecosystems. It also marks its willingness to make Article 8 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union a reality rather than a mere will. However, the Union must ask itself the question of its effectiveness in terms of gender equality within the European Community itself. Although it has made much progress over the past 50 years, there are still many efforts to be made in terms of employment or equal pay. Although the average wage gap is 16.3%, it should be pointed out that not all EU countries struggle with the same force against wage discrimination. We can take the example of Estonia with a gap of 25.3%, whereas it stands at 5.2% in Romania. Moreover, the EU's average equality index (52.9%) perfectly illustrates the efforts we still need to make. It is therefore necessary to step up our work in order to improve the quality of life of our citizens and to make the Union a global example.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the Commission statement on strengthening the fight against violence against women and girls and the Istanbul Convention by EU Member States (2018/2625 (RSP))

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, gender-based violence and harassment are persistent problems in Europe. We are all familiar with the figures: from the age of 15, one in three women in Europe has been a victim of physical violence, sexual violence or both; 55% of women are victims of sexual harassment. Violence against women is a violation of human rights. The Commission takes the fight against this very seriously, which is why we made 2017 the year of action to combat violence against women. In June 2017 the EU signed the Council of Europe’s Istanbul Convention on the prevention and protection of victims of gender-based violence. The Commission’s intention is to conclude full EU ratification as soon as possible. I would like to thank the European Parliament for constantly speaking out alongside the Commission about the importance of ratifying the Council of Europe Convention on prevention and protection of victims of gender-based violence. Despite the fact that all EU countries have signed the Convention and 17 have so far ratified it, we see strong opposition against ratification in a few countries. The Convention has generated very intense public debates where there have been misconceptions and misleading arguments. For example, these concern the use and translation of the term ‘gender’. They concern the fear that ratifying the Convention would mean forcing states to allow same-sex marriage or to introduce a new refugee status for transgender or intersex persons. Let me be very clear on this. The Convention is about preventing and combating violence against women without other hidden purposes. It is not an instrument for shaping gender perceptions or ideologies. It applies to women who become victims of violence simply because they are women. The Convention does not oblige states to allow same-sex marriage. In fact, no reference is made to the legal recognition of same-sex marriages: this subject is outside of the scope of the Convention. It also does not oblige states to have their schools give lessons about sexual orientation or gender identity. Nowhere in the Convention is it stated that a new refugee status should be established for transgender or intersex persons or for any other group. The Convention requires parties to introduce a gender-sensitive perspective into the examination of asylum requests to take into account why and how women experience persecution – for example, the risk of female genital mutilation. I sincerely hope that those Member States that still have doubts about joining the Convention will consider its fundamental purpose: to prevent violence against women and to support and protect those women who fall victim to violence.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, six months ago, we were here adopting EU accession to the Istanbul Convention with a large majority. Today, we are here again. We are not going to quit until women are free from violence. The Convention is the only binding treaty that criminalises violence against women and domestic violence. It defines violence done to a woman just because she is a woman, based on sexism and discrimination. It is about women being harassed, beaten up, raped or killed, and girls forced to marry or mutilated. It is not about any ideology or religion.  Last June, I proudly represented Parliament at the signature of the EU accession to the Convention, a historic step towards preventing those horrible crimes, combating impunity and protecting victims. Since then, Estonia, Cyprus and Germany have ratified it, and now we urge the 11 remaining Member States to ratify it. There has been much misrepresentation of the Convention, for instance, in Bulgaria, Croatia, Poland, Slovakia, and even Ukraine. The Council of Europe Commissioner for Human Rights recently clarified that the arguments pretending that the word ‘gender’ has hidden purposes are simply not true. He said that it means the socially constructed roles and behaviours that a society considers appropriate for women and men. It is about combating stereotypes. It is not against the traditional family. It is violence that endangers families, not the Convention.  Today, we call on the EU and the Council of Europe to do more, in dialogue with Member States, on the issue of gender, engaging with civil society, religious groups and women NGOs, we call on the Presidency to put this issue on the agenda of the European Council for as long as it takes, and we call on Bulgaria to reopen the ratification process. There is no other gender equality issue worth discussing for as long as women continue to be abused. As co—rapporteur on the Istanbul Convention, I can say that we remain committed to zero tolerance of violence against women.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, why are we meeting again to discuss the Istanbul Convention? I would have liked to say that we are here to welcome the ratification by the European Union and all the Member States. I would have liked to say, “Yes, combating violence against women is a top priority because these are serious human rights violations”. But no, the reality is much more disappointing. We are here because of a movement of rejection and protest around this convention. The Slovak Prime Minister openly declares that he refuses to ratify it because it would be contrary to its Constitution, and the Bulgarian government — while Bulgaria holds the presidency of the Council — withdrew its ratification bill a few days ago. It's deplorable. National debates have been distorted by false arguments and misconceptions. No, the term “gender” does not contain any hidden ideology, but it describes the phenomenon of gender-based violence that targets women because they are women. Let us not be fooled: the refusal to legislate on violence against women is a symptom of a general regression of our rights in Europe that also affects sexual rights. How many barriers stand in front of women who wish to have an abortion today? I am addressing here to the eleven Member States which have not yet ratified the Convention or, worse, who refuse to do so. I insurge against your choice and I strongly denounce any blocking or turning back. The whole European Parliament is calling on you to apply this effective legislation, which is simply aimed at protecting victims and prosecuting those responsible. The result will be a more peaceful, just and more protective society. As for ratification by the Union itself, the negotiations are not successful because the Conseil is retreating behind legal arguments that are unfounded. I ask you, Mr Vice-President, to stand up so that this whole process will really help the lives of women everywhere in Europe.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President! Dear ladies! As a consequence, the Istanbul Convention is intended to protect women from violence. In fact, it primarily serves to implement a left-wing worldview, for the purposes of the convention, which are to prevent violence against women, to protect its victims and to prosecute perpetrators, no one disputes. But they are, Madam President, embedded in a controversial ideological context centered around a gendered vision of a society in which gender has a socio-cultural basis rather than a genetic fact. I encourage you to read the convention and get acquainted with it. Unfortunately, this left-wing need to introduce an ideological cultural revolution for nothing has respect for treaties and the principle of subsidiarity. The Union is once again trying to interfere where there is no competence. These issues lie within the competence of the Member States.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Madam President, thank you, Commissioner, it hurts me to hear Members saying things like those I have just heard from Mrs Wiśniewska. I really find it very hard at this point, after the years we have been on this subject, since 2014, to hear something that has nothing to do with the Istanbul Convention. The Istanbul Convention is the best and most comprehensive legally binding tool ever given against gender-based and domestic violence. I mean, it goes beyond violence against women. He does not mean to tell women how they should live, he only asks for legal measures that protect them and persecute and penalize their aggressors. There are countries in the Union that are making up a story around. What ideology are they talking about? What ideology are they talking about? Why are they getting out of their manga now talk about the genre as something that is not? Here we are asking the countries of the European Union, and this Parliament has supported it from the outset, to show that they do not need to protect and prosecute the aggressors a convention like this, or to support it. And it turns out that we have countries that not only do not ratify it, but are withdrawing. We have the country that is currently holding the presidency, Bulgaria, which is withdrawing; Poland, Croatia, Hungary, what is happening? I would like to thank Greece for ratifying it, at least there is some common sense. What are we talking about? Do we agree that prejudices which seek to keep women subordinate to men and on a non-equality level are not compatible with the Union's values? I think so, and we must also teach children what those values of respect are. And I ask all European governments to please ratify the Istanbul Convention and show that they live up to the European Union of which they claim to be a member.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, colleagues, let’s face it: we are experiencing a major backlash on women’s rights in the European Union. Many of us actually grew up believing that there is only one direction in which women’s rights could go, namely that we would become more and more protected and that we would gain more rights over the years. That is simply not the case anymore, because we see attacks on women’s rights all over the European Union and those who are attacking women’s rights have now chosen the Istanbul Convention as one of the battlefields in this discussion. They are doing that for purely ideological reasons. They are not doing that on the basis of any scientific or real arguments; they are doing that because they want to push forward their ideology of taking away our rights. We will not give up; we will not be afraid of that. The suffragettes, 100 years ago, in many parts of Europe fought for the right of women to vote. We will be the generation of feminists that will make sure that women are protected from gender-based violence all over the European Union. We will ratify the Istanbul Convention all over the European Union and make sure that there is an end to gender-based violence.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, what a surprise, a few days after Women's Day we are discussing the Istanbul Convention! It is regrettable to discuss gender violence and women's rights only on the occasion of global days but also scandals. Do not forget that every day attacks occur on women and young girls. They live in fear and try to close their wounds. In them it does not mean much that the Union signed the Convention. We need strategy and action, which is why I call on the Commission to answer us: firstly, when will it bring a specific strategy for implementing the Convention; secondly, how much money will it allocate; thirdly, what programmes it will plan and fourthly, if it intends to appoint a special authority for the implementation of the Convention; combating violence in the European Union.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I consider it a good thing that we have to discuss violence against women on a regular basis in this House. However, while we debate, crimes against women do not hint at diminishing. The black chronicle feeds on tragedies that we often mourn when it is too late by now. My country ratified the Istanbul Convention in 2013, yet the dramatic counts of new victims continues, which by virtue of it would have to be saved. I am talking about women who have denounced their needles in vain, I am talking about a system that is evidently not yet able to put an end to unacceptable forms of daily violence. Luckily something moves, at least in the consciousness and awareness of women, who begin to rip off the unbearable veil of shame and fear, and who find the courage to denounce hateful crimes, which for too long have been silent or ignored. All this is not enough, however, and there is clearly a need for further concrete action on the part of the Union and the Member States to protect women.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: - Madam President! The Istanbul Convention is the best modern tool for combating violence against women, the gold standard of anti-overpower policy, the ready roadmap for building national anti-violence programs. This convention was signed by all countries in the European Union and the majority ratified it. And since Poland — my country — was mentioned earlier in the context of gender discussions, I would like to inform you that Poland has signed and ratified the convention as one of the first countries. We had a gender discussion, but most of us were convinced that this convention should be signed and ratified because it is of value. A key part of the convention, which constitutes its distinguished position among similar documents, is the chapter on prevention. It talks about preventing violence against women, combining this prevention of violence with equality. This relationship is very clear: the more equality, the less violence. Against the background of high ratings of the Convention as a road map in combating violence, and in the context of the equality thread, it is incomprehensible for me that the European Union, which is the world leader in promoting equality between women and men, has signed this convention to a very narrow extent. Thus, the European Union, represented by the Commission and the Council, has not itself abdicated from its functions as guardian and promoter of equality, although the Treaty, particularly the Charter of Fundamental Rights, gives the Union considerable powers in this regard. I therefore call on the European Commission to revise the extent to which the Union has acceded to the Convention, specifically to extend it to other articles of the Convention where the Union shares its competence with the Member States under law.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: Madam President, Commissioner, one in three women in the European Union may be the victim of gender-based violence. And to hear some statements such as those which we have had to hear here in this Parliament seem to me of serious irresponsibility. To say that the Istanbul Convention is a weapon on the left, really, is to disrespect reality. The Istanbul Convention is an international legal instrument to compromise the action of all countries to combat the greatest social scourge currently existing, in the world and in Europe. Women are being killed for the mere fact of being women, and we cannot allow there to still be eleven countries in Europe that have not ratified this Convention. On March 8, the streets were dyed purple. Millions of women and men around the world, in Europe, took to the streets, stopped to say that this world has to be more equal, to claim the fight for equality, but also to tell women victims that they are not alone. The women and men who took to the streets gave an example of what governments have to do at this time. Therefore, let us not allow it to be lost one more minute. Let's be responsible, because we're talking about women's lives. The excuses being made right now are totally unacceptable. We will therefore continue to work to ensure that there is not one more woman killed by sexist terrorism.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: Madam President, we are discussing here a consequence, one of the concrete consequences, of this conservative and populist wave that is going through much of Europe. We agree that gender-based violence is a serious human rights problem affecting millions of women. We have endowed ourselves with an advanced instrument of international law to combat this violence, and yet we see how there are States that are reluctant to ratify the best instrument we have. And those who resist make excuses, talk to us about gender ideology, invented consequences of ratification that do not exist. Ladies and gentlemen, this is not about ideologies, this is about defending human rights, and the defence of human rights is neither left nor center nor right, it is an obligation of all. I therefore call on the European Commission, the Council, the majority of this House, to do everything we can to ensure ratification of the Convention by all Member States.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: – Madam President, violence against women and girls is an issue of democracy, but it is also a question of life and death. The Istanbul Convention is an instrument of human rights law, the best international instrument that we have to work on prevention, protection and prosecution. The EU has signed it. All the EU Member States have signed it, but there are 11 that have not ratified it, among them the country holding our Presidency – Bulgaria. It is a shame that nobody from the Presidency is here to see how they can take this forward in the Council.  Now we have some Member States that actually say that they are questioning it altogether. It is unacceptable and, as has been said, a sign of general regression for women’s rights. The Istanbul Convention is not an ideological battle, other than the one to end violence against women and girls, and that is perhaps political and ideological enough. It does not give rights to LGBTI people either. I must say that I am appalled by the homophobia that I have heard. Those who attack the Istanbul Convention are attacking women’s rights and LGBTI rights. They attack all of us. But it will not work because we will stand up to you. We will make the world a safe place for women, girls and LGBTI people.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combating of Gender Violence is the best instrument of supranational force. It captures in the best possible way the mentality with which we must nurture future generations in all the lengths and breadth of the earth. The slogan “zero tolerance to violence” is based on a very specific logic. We denounce and condemn all acts of gender violence, bring the perpetrators to justice, protect and support the victims. The European Union must continue to be a pioneer in gender equality and the fight against violence, through strategies that inform, educate and sensitize men and women, and each of us in our position to become a carrier of hope and awakening for the prevention and treatment of aggressive behaviour. Above all, however, we have an obligation to make it clear that no legislative text alone is enough to change the reality if morbid attitudes and attitudes are not permanently eliminated.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President! Time and again we are concerned with the Istanbul Convention, even though it was drafted in 2011. In fact, all of this should be a matter of course by now, and we should actually be proud of it — proud that the members of the Council of Europe agreed at the time to outlaw all forms of violence against women and to take concrete measures to combat them. Obviously, however, it is not possible to complete the whole thing accordingly This cannot be explained by a misunderstanding, even with the slowness of decision-making structures. There is a suspicion that some simply do not want women to be equal to men in every way. Arguments are particularly absurd that the Convention would contribute to the division of society. The opposite is the case: a society that allows violence against women, which divides. And it is particularly disconcerting when a Member State which currently holds the Presidency of the Council and is not present today refuses to ratify the Convention.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, the Istanbul Convention is a key instrument for the fight against gender-based violence. When I speak with women’s rights defenders from all over the world, I realise how lucky we are to have such an instrument in Europe. This is why I find it appalling that this Convention’s ratification is so problematic in some Member States, including my own. The fact that governments are reluctant to ratify this key instrument shows how little they care about women’s safety. In some countries the excuse is that the government cannot afford to ratify and implement the Convention. In these cases, I say that not to do so will cost women’s lives.  In Bulgaria, the use of transphobic and homophobic arguments against this Convention is very disappointing. It is therefore particularly worrying in the context of the Bulgarian Presidency of the Council. I call on the Bulgarian Government to revise its position on this crucial issue and stand by the Istanbul Convention.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: Madam President, violence against women has been perpetuated through a culture of tolerance and denial. That is why it was a big step when the European Union adopted the Istanbul Convention, and we did so because it is the only instrument that provides a global response to gender-based violence, the only tool that develops a strategy to prevent violence, to protect victims and to prosecute criminals. The Istanbul Convention also creates awareness of gender-based violence: a clear violation of human rights. We therefore call on the Commission and the Council to act as a driving force and urgently to carry out an action plan for all the countries of the European Union to ratify the Istanbul Convention. My country, Spain, did it in 2014, but there are still eleven countries that have not ratified it and, ladies and gentlemen, they have to do so because we are talking about justice, not ideology.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a few days ago yet another episode of violence against women shocked Italy: a law enforcement man, armed with his own ordinance gun, fired against his family, killing two daughters and seriously injuring his wife. In all newspapers it was written that this happened because the woman had asked for separation. I find this phrase of obscurantism unacceptable, which makes us realise how much way there is still to go. What happened happened because the man was a violent man and regarded his own wife as something his property. The Istanbul convention certainly did so much, but it is on a cultural level that the way to go is uphill. In the heritage of knowledge that bases our beliefs more than we think, woman is never represented as an individual who finds full self-expression in their professional role. And with the economic crisis the situation has worsened as women are among the hardest-hit categories. The main work must be done on the cultural models that our society continues to propose to us.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: — Dear Madam President, the family is difficult, but you have tried to pronounce it, honourable Members, I represent Bulgaria and the Bulgarian Government, and with dissatisfaction I have heard from you quite unmeasured words regarding the Bulgarian position. And they are due to the reason that we have seen now and in this House — most of you have proved that the conversation about this document is political and it is about left-wing positions. I understand that some of my colleagues want to play communism and left-wing positions, but they just haven't lived in communism. Any violence is unacceptable and we are against violence against women, of course, and we will be against it. But quite obviously in this document there is an ideology, a gender ideology. And these things need to be clarified and removed from this document. And no one will be against it. And it's not just about Bulgaria. Here we are talking about the UK, which is a serious Western country. And we are talking about other countries that have doubts about this ratification. Therefore, please respect the internal order and the right of every society to sort its own internal order.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: — Madam President, talking about the implementation of the Istanbul Declaration and combating any form of violence against women requires going well beyond statements of intent. It calls for the implementation of political options that the European Union has opposed. It requires the creation of support facilities within the framework of a public policy based on investment in public services and the social functions of the State. It requires looking at violence in all its forms, be it violence at work or high rates of exploitation and precariousness, or to recognize the violence of poverty or the violence that translates into unacceptable pressures on motherhood and the rights associated with them and which are so often denied. It demands prostitution as a serious form of violence and exploitation of women, which some now want to legitimize and legalize in Portugal. Ensuring the protection of women victims of violence requires public responses that increase the resources and effective responses of the State and intervene in the prevention of its economic, social, psychological and cultural causes.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: Madam President, if you attack one, you attack them all. The tragedy continues. Day by day, the number of women killed and suffering violence increases. Ladies sexist ladies, they do not serve arguments of ideology to try to circumvent the law. That's political hypocrisy. There is permanent feminicide, victims of violence against women must be protected more throughout Europe. There are data that one in three women has suffered sexual, physical or psychological harassment — it is unacceptable. That is why the European Commission must act as a feminist lobby, like the lobbying that took place in the strike of 8 March. Member States must ratify the Istanbul Convention with more investment.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, violence against women is a violation of human rights and condemnation of such incidents is non-negotiable. But nothing justifies the treatment of legal instruments to promote ideological beliefs, nor is it acceptable to exert irregular pressure on Member States to take the form of sovereign decisions rather than to be supported in the implementation of their commitments. The overall response to gender-based violence against men and women is being confronted by such controversial texts. These promote unilateral definitions, dictate criteria for granting international protection status and impose changes in national education systems which ultimately oppose the citizens of the Union. I call on the Commission to limit itself to supporting information, awareness-raising and cooperation at Union level and finally to allow Member States to meet the challenges with appropriate methods, according to their specific needs.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: — Madam President, I will not repeat my doubts about the specific provisions of the Istanbul Convention. Suffice it to say that I also share them with me most of the citizens I represent here. Combating violence against women, assisting its victims, as well as education as part of the prevention of violence, are among the exclusive powers of the Member States. To date, only seventeen of them have ratified the Istanbul Convention. The Istanbul Convention is not synonymous with combating violence against women and girls. It is only one particular political tool that has strengths, but also shortcomings. The European Treaties give each Member State the right to independently assess the pros and cons of this Convention and to decide. Both this Parliament and the Commission should respect that.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, you have given some figures and, yes, it is frightening to see that more than 55% of women are harassed or endure domestic violence or at work. My problem is whether we really know what the figure is, because a lot of women endure violence and are afraid to say. They fear precisely that they will not be further assaulted. 2017 was the year of combating violence, we have an improvement compared to the last years. It is very important to go to the cause. I believe that, in fact, the cause of violence is education, and I believe that we do not do enough, none of the Member States, for education, especially in rural areas, where women, in particular, suffer violence. And then we have another problem: in very many Member States, we do not have the protection of women, victims, we do not have shelters, we do not have measures taken against men who commit violence against women. So that's the thing, and I think we need to go with concrete steps to resolve it. Ratification is not enough. We have enough directives, laws, regulations that don't apply. Women's lives are non-negotiable and no one has to endure any more violence. That is why we need to be united, all of Europe, to combat violence against women.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Madam President, the protection of women and other family members from violence to all Member States must be high on the list of priorities. But problems with ratifying the Istanbul Convention arose not because of the reluctance of member states to protect women from violence, but because of controversial parts of the Convention itself. First of all, it is problematic that it equates state institutions dealing with human rights with civil society associations, and gives the expert body Grevio too much powers in implementation. When we add that states take on themselves the obligation to finance NGOs to the extent that GREVIO considers appropriate, it is clear that they are losing some of their sovereignty. The convention, I believe, would have long been ratified by all members of the Union if it focused only on protecting women from violence, without promoting gender theory and trying to unravel nation states. This is why I once again call on the Croatian authorities not to ratify the Istanbul Convention for the reasons mentioned above.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think it is important to address the debate on the ratification of the Istanbul Convention a few days after the demonstrations on 8 March, the global strike for women from productive and reproductive work, from genres, ruolizations. I believe that this movement, the feminist movement Not One Less, had the ability to nominate with an intersectional gaze, holding together criticism of class, race and sex domination, all forms of patriarchal male violence against women, and has been able to name, as a transfeminist movement, also criticism of heteronormative patriarchy. This Parliament must give answers to this movement, and I believe that working for the European Union and the Member States to ratify and respect the Istanbul Convention would be a minimal response to what this movement is asking for.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, violence against women cannot be tolerated in our society. It should be fought with every means available. The Istanbul Convention will reinforce measures to prevent this violence and to protect women from it. It will make our society a safer place for women and girls. We have to do everything in our power to stop violence against women and to support the victims. Ratification of the Convention by the European Union is an important step and a powerful signal for all the victims, showing that the EU takes their situation seriously and is acting to end the violence.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: in writing. — In reference to the debate held on 12 March 2018 on the European Commission's statement on the ratification of the Istanbul Convention, in which Poland was listed among the countries opposed to the Convention in connection with the 'promotion of gender ideology', I would like to explain the following: Poland actually had a very heated debate on the Convention and - as in many other countries - the “gender ideology” thread was present in it. However, the initiator of the signing and ratification of the Convention was the Polish government, supported by the Polish Sejm and civil society, engaged in anti-movement activities, and the main opponent - the hierarchical Catholic Church, which issued official statements on “gender ideology”, as well as MPs from the right of the political scene. text: in writing. — All the Member States of the European Union have signed the Istanbul Convention, but eleven have yet to ratify it. Impunity is no longer tolerable, and any blockage or reverse gear is unacceptable. In order to ensure a coherent framework to combat violence against women across Europe, all Member States and the Union must ratify the Convention as soon as possible.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. — It is the right of Member States to accept or refuse the ratification of any international convention, including the Istanbul Convention, independently, respecting the opinion of their own citizens. To argue that the fight against violence against women is only possible and exclusively by ratifying the Istanbul Convention is incorrect and unfounded. Croatia has already incorporated into its legislation all 48 measures and mechanisms to combat violence against women envisaged by the Convention. Therefore, there is no need to ratify it and thus enable the introduction of provisions which do not in any way relate to the fight against violence against women, but directly violate the principle of subsidiarity and fundamental human rights guaranteed by existing, legally valid national and international provisions. For this reason, it is necessary to refuse the implementation of the ideology imposed through the vague and ideologically coloured definition of “genus.” Gender as a legal term does not exist and is an unscientific concept, therefore it is wrong and unfounded to conditional Member States to introduce such a term because it brings nothing but a climate of legal uncertainty.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: in writing. — Let's not fool ourselves and obscure some ideological platitudes. Violence against women is a fact, and I'm not talking about statistics here because I agree that they are not measurable. Why? Because many women don't report these crimes, particularly when they take place at home or in the family. This just means there is more to crime against women than official figures indicate. The Istanbul Convention, which aims to counter violence and help women victims of crime, has been interpreted by some environments through the prism of incomprehensible concerns that have no reference in the text. Many lies have already been rooted in our citizens' consciousness. The convention doesn't impose recognition of single-sex marriages on countries, it doesn't even impose a duty on sex education. I support the position of the European Commission and many of my colleagues who are fervently in favour of ratification by the Member States of the Istanbul Convention as soon as possible. However, I would like to emphasise that ratification is just the beginning, the main thing is the subsequent implementation of the Convention's tenets in order to effectively and effectively counter violence against women and girls and to help victims of crime in practice. As Poland's example shows — ratifying and signing the convention does not prevent the current government from taking public funding away from institutions carrying legal aid and guaranteeing care for women who are in dramatic life situations.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Lucy Anderson, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on delivery services Cross-border parcels (COM (2016) 0285 - C8-0195/2016 - 2016/0149 (COD)) (A8-0315/2017).

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I am delighted to have the chance to present to Parliament this new regulation on cross-border parcels. The regulation started out as a proposal in 2016 as part of the European Commission’s Digital Single Market Strategy, with the objective of helping to boost cross-border e—commerce by improving parcel delivery. Thanks to the hard work of many MEP colleagues and staff, the Commission and the Estonian Presidency, we have a provisionally agreed text today. I urge everyone to support this text in the form of the new cross-border parcels regulation in tomorrow’s vote. The initial aims of the regulation were to help secure a more efficient parcel sector, increase transparency of tariffs, and assess prices where necessary. Together, I believe we have secured these aims and also added a stronger focus on consumer needs and the interests of small- and medium-sized enterprises when ordering goods from other EU countries. As emphasised in recital 2 of this regulation, Article 14 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union highlights the place occupied by services of general economic interest, such as postal and parcel services, in the shared values of the Union, as well as their role in promoting social and territorial cohesion.  The main elements of the regulation are as follows: we have agreed to expand the scope of key provisions to a certain extent where necessary to all cross-border parcel delivery service providers, not just those designated as providing a universal service. This is right, especially since universal service providers do not always have a large share of the cross-border parcels market. The regulation also covers multinationals and newer players in the parcel sector, including those with alternative business models. On the provision of information to national regulators, Article 4 applies not only to cross—order parcel operators, but to all parcel delivery companies, other than those with fewer than 50 persons working for them. Regulators can also, where justified, include smaller companies with between 25 and 49 workers. As part of this duty, parcel companies will give information each year on the employment status of workers delivering parcels, along with details of the sub-contractors they use.
