This, in my view, will help to expose the activities of some businesses who do not give their parcel workforce proper terms and conditions of employment, and instead require them to operate on a self-employed or precarious basis. It is encouraging that this aspect of the regulation has been particularly welcomed by trade unions. Rules on cross-border parcel tariffs in Articles 5 and 6 empower and enable national authorities more specifically to monitor delivery prices and assess cross-border prices that they deem unreasonably high. Whilst the regulation does not impose a cap on prices, it will allow users more easily to compare domestic and cross-border tariffs. Parcel companies will have to disclose prices ,and these will be published by the Commission on a dedicated website. Where parcel delivery is subject to universal service obligations, authorities will have a clearer power to investigate further, where necessary, taking into account the likely impact of prices, including on anyone who is disabled or who has reduced mobility, and smaller companies and citizens in remote areas.  The factors that authorities shall take into account in any assessment also include any relevant costs, quality of service standards and volumes, as well as tariffs of comparable parcel delivery services providers. The existence of price regulation and abuses of dominant market position may also be taken into account, if necessary. These provisions have been drafted, as has the regulation as a whole – and I emphasise this point with care – to make sure that the principles of the Postal Services Directive are not undermined or contradicted. In line with the 2011 Consumer Rights Directive, Article 7 of this regulation emphasises that consumers are to be provided with proper information on delivery options and charges payable and complaints-handling policies, where applicable. Given the concrete evidence on problems with parcel deliveries in quite a few cases, I would have preferred this provision to be stronger, but it is still a good start. There is indeed plenty of evidence on problems with parcel deliveries. Finally, I am pleased that the Commission is working with the support of Parliament on a comprehensive study on parcel delivery, and the regulation underlines that standardisation work should include environmental considerations and require a first review two years after entry into force, including on affordability, consumer protection and standards issues.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the IMCO Committee. — Mr. President, about 11 million packages are delivered every day in the European Union. Shipping prices are non-transparent, with some postal operators and consumer groups at an extremely disadvantaged position. This Regulation introduces an order on a very illogical market according to which, for example, one-way delivery was three times more expensive than delivery for the same distance in the other direction. This Regulation will also result in the growth of e-commerce. Delivery is the most important factor for consumers when buying online. As many as 70% of European Union citizens complain that their delivery is too expensive, and 50% of them do not know what to do in case of problems. That is why I am particularly pleased that the obligation has been adopted to provide the consumer when buying all forms of delivery available to him, with a price comparison. Also, before buying must inform the consumer what to do in case of problems. I want to thank my shadow reporters on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee and colleague Lucy Anderson for a great job done.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would first like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Anderson, the shadow rapporteurs and the Chair of the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN). Thanks to your hard work, we were able to reach an agreement on this regulation on cross-border parcel delivery services last December. It is an important step for eCommerce and the Digital Single Markets.  Today’s rules do not support cross-border eCommerce. 68% of internet users in the European Union shopped online last year, but only 33% of these e—shoppers bought goods or services from sellers based in another EU country. 17% of SMEs in the European Union sold online in 2016, but only 7.5% of SMEs did so across borders.  High delivery prices are one of the reasons why the potential of cross-border eCommerce still remains untapped in the European Union. They are a major concern for consumers and companies, especially SMEs. Delivery prices vary a lot across Europe, often without justification. On average, someone who sends a two-kilogram parcel to another EU country pays three to five times more than the domestic price. In some cases, it is much higher – up to 22 times as high. With this new regulation, we are addressing these issues through more price transparency and a stronger role for regulators. A month ago, I was here for the debates on the regulation against unjustified geo-blocking. Today, I am pleased that we can fill in another new and important piece of the puzzle, building on other recent agreements to simplify VAT rules for eCommerce and to strengthen consumer protection. Step by step, we are creating a Digital Single Market. Thank you for your support.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. A fully integrated European internal market for consumers also includes the fact that products purchased across borders also come to customers, safely and cost-effectively. Unfortunately, we in Europe are still a long way from this point. To give just one example: how can it be that a package from Brussels to Aachen is about four times as expensive as a package from Munich to Berlin, even though that is four times ahead? It soon becomes apparent what is at stake. In any case, this has nothing to do with national wage structures or transport costs. We already have the impression that some providers take advantage of people having no sense of what a cross-border package can cost. That is why the central objective of this regulation is to create price transparency, particularly for consumers, but also for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are particularly suffering from excessive prices, but which also want to take advantage of the opportunities of the internal market in Internet trade. We in the Group of the European People's Party will support this agreement. I would like to thank the rapporteur. It took us a little time to move towards each other, but then we found a good solution, which in the end also convinced the Council to the greatest extent. I am sure that this regulation will also give us falling consumer prices for a short time or a long time, and that was worth all the effort.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Mr President, Commission, ladies and gentlemen. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Lucy Anderson, and the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent work, which ultimately led to a good, sustainable compromise. Because it is clear that online retail has increased significantly in recent years. We see that it already accounts for 3% of GDP, gross domestic product, and it is growing significantly, especially in the cross-border area. I believe that the compromise can also be seen because we have been able to negotiate some improvements for customers, for example in terms of price transparency, but also, above all, in terms of consumer protection. In future, for example, as far as market surveillance is concerned, national regulatory authorities will ultimately have to provide parcel delivery under universal service obligations. Check the tariffs. All around this is a good solution. Thanks again to everyone who contributed.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the e-commerce of the 21st century is a beautiful combination of the free movement of goods and the freedom to provide services. This creates enormous opportunities, and it is important that it does so throughout the European Union. We wanted to make sure that these opportunities are not just for large companies, large operators and large—scale platforms, but also for small retailers and small craft shops that can then rely on reliable and affordable services. So we have taken an important step in this direction, even though – if it were up to me – we would have gone even further. I am glad that the proposals that I made in terms of the scope – and that is single piece parcel services’ tariffs – has been taken on board, because that will in fact enable us to compare like with like. Every single operator, regardless of size, will have to make his or her tariffs public, and they can then be independently reviewed, if need be, by national regulators.  If anyone expected that parcels would be cheaper tomorrow, this is bad news, but we have made significant progress towards greater transparency, more competition and more clarity for consumers in the future. We have fallen short – and I am happy to say so – of price regulation, which was also in the air. I would like to thank the rapporteur, my colleagues and the shadow rapporteurs. I think that we should clearly vote ‘yes’ in favour in the coming hours.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, Members of the National Front will vote against this report on the delivery of parcels between Member States for a company name. Reducing the cost of deliveries at any cost will be to the detriment of the working conditions of employees, already largely victims of hidden work, abusive use of service providers and seconded work. Contraindications also to preserve the financial balance of the structures responsible for the public service, which is only possible thanks to the concurrent delivery of parcels. Reducing margins and increasing competition will necessarily harm him. The pious vows about universal service will, of course, serve as a pretext for the so-called left, joined with generalized economic liberalism to vote favourably. Against last, since on the ecological front, the intensification of links will aggravate polluting emissions, even though, in the transport sector, this argument is debated until nausea to encourage new taxes. Encouraging short circuits would be a real ecological and social solution, a solution never addressed because it is contrary to the financial interests of multinationals and the dogmas of the single market.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, the undeniable fact is that the prices of cross-border parcels are relatively high. The famous liberalisation of postal services has not led to lower prices for citizens or for small and medium-sized enterprises. For specific products online sales are prohibitive due to high postage prices. Unfortunately, however, it is difficult to deal with this problem. We will have to return to the model of operation of the national La Poste and to treat them essentially as infrastructure of the state. Yes to private initiative, but without undermining and degrading the public character of La Poste in favour of giant multinationals. I find it unacceptable to subsidise private companies with taxpayers' money, in order to provide services provided until a few years ago by public mail to all residents of the country, wherever they are, on a stable basis, affordable price and fixed quality. The following criteria, which are important in the postal sector, must be ensured: to be accessible to all, to comply with the rules of fair competition, to be proportionate to the cost of providing services and, finally, to comply with the rules of transparency and publicity. In addition, private postal companies have often given very negative samples of writing, with violations of insurance and labour rights. Finally, with regard to parcel shipments within states, there are already supervisory authorities and there is nothing more than coordination between them in order to regulate cross-border shipments.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: — Mr President, this regulation on cross-border parcel services is indeed a welcome step towards a more efficient internal market and a good continuation of the last adopted ban on land restrictions, namely geoblocking. It is understood that high delivery fees are one of the biggest barriers to making purchases online from other member countries, as shipping a package between EU countries might cost up to five times more than intra-country shipments. Accordingly, with this change, we will now hopefully be able to boost online commerce and increase transparency and efficiency in the EU single market. But at the same time as we put the internal market in order in this sense, I would like to raise one major grievance and it is the Chinese online shopping in the European market. I know that Commissioner Ansip is very familiar with this issue, and that the important element here is, above all, the development country tariff for Chinese mail. It is now distorting the competition in the ecommerce market in Europe. Is there anything in the Commission that could be done quickly on this issue?

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: — Mr President, if someone wants to send a parcel to another Member State today, they may be unmildly surprised, whether by how much they pay for such a service or by the manner of delivery of their consignment. Unfortunately, information about prices and conditions of delivery is often unclear and incomplete. European Parliament negotiators, headed by Social Democratic rapporteur Lucy Anderson, made improvements during a trialogue with the Council, such as on the transparency of rates for consumers and businesses or the powers of regulators to assess the disproportionality of prices. I also consider it a success that the new rules will apply to all major players in the parcel delivery industry, including online shopping. However, it is important to have the working conditions of the people who work in this sector. Price competition cannot be to their detriment.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Mr President! Parcel delivery, this is something that we are engaged in today much more than about 15 or 20 years ago in our daily lives. However, parcel delivery is also highly competitive and characterized by a fast pace that the Internet is of course imposing on us today. A total of four billion parcels are shipped per year in Europe. That is, someone orders them, and someone delivers them to someone too. It is very often obscure how this process is happening and, above all, how prices are formed, and this is very difficult, especially for consumers in Europe. In this respect, I am also in favour of this initiative, which creates transparency for consumers. On the other hand, of course, it is also a good idea to argue about how much we should intervene in this market, because market regulation also always means that I am, of course, moving the market in a certain direction in some way. It is therefore also a massive encroachment on entrepreneurial freedom and a considerable amount of bureaucracy, which still needs to be assessed whether it is really worthwhile.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: Mr President, I would above all like to congratulate Lucy Anderson, because whenever she makes a report she does very well and it has been a pleasure, as always, to work with her. From the Group of the European People's Party, we wanted to defend, as we have always done in all reports, small and medium-sized enterprises and consumers. Consumers will have more transparent prices, will be able to buy from suppliers and choose services while better informed. Moreover, this Regulation does not only apply to traditional operators — postal mail. We wanted to ensure that start-ups, that is, new e-commerce platforms, had to report their rates. We argued that today, since goods purchased online reach consumers through numerous agents, they must be included in providing information. However, in order to prevent small local operators from being overflowed with manages, enterprises with less than 50 workers have been excluded. I just hope that does not mean that new business models with strong market breakthrough, such as Amazon, are exempt from providing information.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with the agreement reached in trilogue, transport companies will finally have to provide their regulatory authorities with a set of data to enable them objective assessments and identify market shortcomings. At the state, unfortunately, regulators in many countries do not have access to such data, which hinders the monitoring of competition in markets for parcel delivery. As a result of this agreement, cross-border parcel delivery services in the European Union will be more transparent and better controlled. Greater price transparency and more effective oversight will help increase market efficiency and reduce tariffs, which to date were not always fully justify. Increased transparency will certainly encourage lower prices for citizens, particularly those living in rural areas, and will allow opportunities for development for small and medium-sized enterprises which, as is known, they have limited negotiating power. This regulation puts order in an important industry and is critical to the development of e-commerce. Finally, important is the provision of affordability criteria within the framework of the universal service obligation.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, four billion parcels that are ordered online across the EU each year, and this has the potential to grow much more. 44% of EU consumers buy online, but only 15% order online in another country. Why? Because of concerns about delivery, including the high delivery tariffs. A fully functional digital single market could bring the range of around EUR 415 billion to European economy. This regulation is very important, because it brings efficiency to the sector, transparency of tariffs and terminal rates, and affordable prices. It will make markets work more effectively by making regulatory oversight of the parcels market more effective and consistent. Delivery operators will have to provide national regulatory authorities with appropriate data and transport of tariffs. This will all help consumer confidence, which will help the market to grow. That will help everybody, and we will complete the digital single market.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, I think that the regulation addresses some of the issues that exist, because the cross-border delivery of goods suffers because it is very expensive, and it is very expensive because we have an abuse of the dominant position of private monopolies, which they have actually taken over the space. After liberalisation in the postal sector, what we saw was the development of many private companies and, while this sector is a universal service, in fact these private companies are imposing increased prices, so that we have an unfavourable treatment of consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises. Since this is a universal service, it is obvious that the regulatory authorities must intervene in order to be able to obtain low prices in the cross-border delivery of goods.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: Mr President, this discussion is part of the policies of assaulting the universal postal service as a public service, which the European Union has been promoting for decades. Privatisation and fragmentation of the service is valued and any reference to public service is removed. Deregulation and job precariousness are legitimized, the conditions are created to facilitate the concentration of services, on the one hand, and the degradation and increase in the cost of service to the user. The consequences of your policies are, moreover, clearly evident in the process of degradation of the universal postal service in Portugal, well expressed by the reality of CTT and evidenced in recent months. The privatized company distributes millionaire profits, disengages the main object of its activity, promotes the closure of counters — more than twenty — and announced the dismissal of eight hundred workers. The service has made the service worse and degraded the response, particularly in smaller or more isolated locations. We therefore welcome the struggle of the CTT workers in defending the company and the revocation of its privatisation, taking up the quality public and universal postal service they have always provided.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would again like to thank Parliament for its work on this regulation, which is part of our efforts to improve cross-border parcel delivery in the European Union. The Commission is following closely and welcomes steps to improve interoperability between national networks, as well as the development of technical standards by the European Committee for Standardisation. We are also monitoring progress on the commitments made by European universal service providers to introduce new services, such as cross-border track-and-trace and common labels. Terminal rates are negotiated in the Universal Postal Union, where the European Union is an observer. New rules apply from the beginning of this year and are already lower for China. We are aware of the issue, but it must be agreed among 192 members.  It is essential that we support all these developments by removing obstacles and aligning rules across Europe. This is the aim of the Digital Single Market strategy where we plan to conclude all pending legislative initiatives by the end of this year.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I listened with great interest to all the contributions to that debate. You could tell, particularly from the contributions from colleagues from the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and the Committee on Transport and Tourism, that it was very much a team effort. Thank you very much to everyone for their kind comments. It is absolutely right – and the Commissioner put this well – that this is an important step for eCommerce and for the digital single market. I absolutely agree with that and also that this regulation will go some way towards dealing with the issues around pricing. It also fits in very well with the geo-blocking regulation. In terms of price transparency, we still have some way to go. I welcome the comments from Mr Telička about small retailers and making sure this regulation works for them too. On the point about Chinese companies and tariffs, part of that has to do with issues regarding the universal postal union rules. I do not think that point was answered by the Commission, but we should go back to it. In terms of privatisation and the impact of privatisation, I do agree in principle with the colleague from the GUE/NGL Group, Mr Pimenta Lopes. That is why I made the point at the beginning on Article 14 and the importance of services of general economic interest. We must not trample over the services and workforces that are of key importance for the functioning of the European Union and for our social cohesion. I hope that we can continue to work on this agenda together.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The discussion is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday 13 March 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. – I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on achieving a consensus on this important issue. Some aspects of it were controversial but she was able to build broad consensus. The cost of sending parcels across Europe can vary massively. Even posting the same parcel on the same journey in opposite directions can cost very different amounts to the customer. In order to better understand this market and monitor its proper functioning, the provision of information on tariffs, company structures and staffing are essential. In turn, this gives consumers more transparency and choice. There is still much work to do to improve the functioning of the single market – a market that we in Wales would very much like to remain a member of.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — (PT) For decades, the European Union has been promoting the assault on the universal postal service as a public service, advocating - and imposing - its liberalisation and privatisation. This discussion is in this context and the terms adopted are clear as to the objectives underlying the report. Privatisation and fragmentation of the service is valued and any reference to public service is removed. Deregulation and job precariousness are legitimized. The conditions are created to facilitate the concentration of services, on the one hand, and the degradation and increase of the costs of service to the user, on the other hand. A well-known story. The consequences of these policies are well evident in the process of degradation of universal postal service in Portugal, look at the reality of CTT evidenced in recent months. The privatized company distributes millionaire profits, disregards the main object of its activity, promotes the closure of counters - more than 20 - and announced the redundancy of 800 workers. The service has made the service worse and degraded the response, particularly in smaller or more isolated locations. We therefore welcome the struggle of CTT workers in defending the company and the reversal of its privatisation, resuming the quality public and universal postal service that they have always provided.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: in writing. — The current fees for international parcel delivery services charged by universal service operators are up to five times higher than domestic shipment fees. Prices for delivery of cross-border shipments can vary significantly and are contractual and confusing. The European Parliament wants all citizens to know what they are paying for. That is why we are introducing legislation to increase the transparency of the services provided by the shipment operators and the fees they charge. The new rules will improve cross-border parcel delivery services through greater transparency in rates and an expansion of market surveillance powers enjoyed by regulators. The new rules will make it easier for consumers and entrepreneurs to see which consignment company proposes the most favorable prices. This will encourage consumers to take advantage of a wider range of products and to shop more frequently on the internet. More opportunities will also be gained by retailers, who have so far not had enough puncture power to negotiate better rates.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. — Unlocking the potential of digital commerce goes through finding workable solutions for the physical delivery of parcels across the EU. In practice, this regulation is one of the conditions for completing the EU's digital single market. If we want small and medium-sized enterprises to take advantage of the opportunity to work with customers across Europe, we need to ensure transparency in the formation of supply prices, a clear choice of suppliers of international shipments and more innovation in the sector as well. Territorial and economic cohesion in the EU is also directly dependent on services of general economic interest, such as the delivery of consignments. More supply competition will enable businesses and customers from more remote regions of the EU to get a quality service at reduced costs. Consumers and businesses are often not informed that there are different delivery options. Facilitating access to this information and price-comparison tools are therefore key.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — With increasing growth of the package delivery sector, there is a need for transparency of service prices. Greater transparency would allow consumers to see service prices and choose the most advantageous option, while allowing service providers to compare with other competitors and lead to fair competition. Accessibility of information on prices for delivery services should lead to increased citizens' confidence in cross-border delivery. Also, the accessibility of information falls within the rights of consumers, which must be guaranteed. This decision will increase and access to rural areas, which so far did not have a large and cost-effective choice of services, online store. Croatian citizens, as well as small and medium-sized enterprises, will directly benefit from improving cross-border parcel delivery services as fees for cross-border delivery are reduced. This will have a direct positive effect on the final price of the product, and at the same time the quality of delivery improves. Shipping prices will be expressed and published more transparently to prevent possible malfeasance. In this way, it aims to create a single digital market tailored to consumers, including citizens of the Republic of Croatia.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Written. — Package delivery is a competitive, innovative and rapidly growing area within the sector. Every year, around four billion packages are ordered and delivered to the EU. As many as 44% of EU consumers shop within their own country, and much less, only 15%, shop in another Member State. In doing so, consumers and small businesses in the EU raise concerns mainly when it comes to cross-border delivery of goods and relatively high postal costs, which, of course, raises the final price. Studies have shown that the prices of cross-border packages are on average three times higher than domestic prices. Approximately 40% of the price of cross-border packages cannot be explained by economic factors such as labour costs. High delivery prices and return services are most often the area of criticism expressed by consumers when shopping online online. High delivery prices are also a barrier for e-retailers selling online. More than larger companies are affected by small and medium-sized enterprises. Effective delivery solutions are crucial for businesses and most important for those operating or shipped to border areas. The legal framework, which creates a more transparent, affordable and reliable parcel delivery service, has the potential to increase online purchases of goods. The Package Delivery Directive provides a good example of extending the frameworks for trade in small and medium-sized enterprises, so I support such measures.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: in writing. — There are dynamic changes in the postal market in the EU. On the one hand, the scale and value of traditional postal services is decreasing, with a growing market of delivery reaching 47 per cent of the total postal service in the EU. On the other hand, international shipments are gradually increasing, so that they already account for 11 per cent of the overall value of postal services in the EU. The proposed amendments therefore justifiably reconcile the liberalisation of the market for European postal services with ensuring universal availability for shipments. I want to emphasise strongly that the proposed solutions cannot focus solely on opening up the market to all actors, as they can only be guided by the profit criterion. An equally important criterion must be the availability of services and the provision of reasonable prices.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Peter Lundgren, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2003/59/EC on the initial qualification and periodic training of drivers of certain road vehicles used for the transport of goods or passengers and Directive 2006/126/EC on driving licences (COM (2017) 0047 - C 8-0025/2017 - 2017/0015 (COD)) (A8-0321/2017).

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: rapporteur. — Mr President! The reason I took on this report was really to save the Swedish model of education. We have our transport high schools, where Swedish students are allowed to take driver's licenses, learn how to drive a truck and learn the basics. Once you get the licence, you go to an established ride to accompany everyday work and learn how it works to be a driver. It's the quickest way to learn the profession. There was then a proposal from the Commission that it should not be allowed to do in this way in professional transport. Surely the reason for that was that it was thought it was going to be a form of wage dumping where inexperienced drivers would drive more cheaply. This is not the case in this model of education, however, but here you have an experienced and routine driver as a supervisor who sits alongside and is with the pupil all days. This way the learner also gains very quick insight into how working as a driver works. Another thing that I'm very happy because I got through is what we call electric powered distribution cars. Thus, smaller trucks of 3.5 tonnes will be allowed in future to drive with a B licence and a total weight of up to 4,250 kg. As I see it, it was necessary to do this because when you replace the petrol or diesel engine with an electric motor and a comparatively heavy battery then you have no load capacity left on those cars. Now we have arranged this by allowing B driving licences up to 4,250 kg. I also put forward a proposal on extreme weather conditions, which, as a driver, is quite important to have knowledge of. I myself, as many know, have a background in the transport industry and know what an awkward winter road team might look like. In Norway for example, you have big concerns. Those are very special conditions. There is a legal requirement to bring snow chains on the truck. However, there is no requirement to know how to assemble the snow chains on the truck. Then After all, it doesn't help much if you have the equipment with you but do not have the knowledge of how to use it. So we have also got that into the new, updated proposal. I am also pleased that we received a proposal to start work on setting up an EU register to help police get a tool to detect fake driving licences. It has become increasingly common for national police in different member countries to stop cars and can quickly find that it is a forged licence. This is a big problem. You can log in and order really any authorisation you want, and at a cost of between EUR 300 and 400, a couple of weeks later you get a licence home in the mailbox which is quite impossible for a police patrol to be able to determine at a road check whether it is false or don't. If we get this database in order, we have given national police authorities a tool to detect the fake driving licences and, in that way, create higher security also on our roads.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, the Commission very much welcomes the agreement reached on this proposal in December here in Strasbourg. I want to thank Parliament, particularly the rapporteur, Mr Lundgren, and the Committee on Transport and Tourism as well as the Council for their constructive and positive approach that allowed reaching a compromise so quickly. I am particularly pleased that in the negotiations all sides followed the rationale and the key objective of the Commission’s proposal, primarily to strengthen the safety on our roads. We should always keep in mind, why we are doing all this. Every year, too many families have to deal with the terrible effects of the severe injuries inflicted to a quarter of a million people because of traffic accidents. Even worse, every year more than 25 000 people die on EU roads. That is a bus load every day. The Commission is strongly engaged with the Member States and also with you, in the Parliament, to turn this situation around and stop this silent killer on our roads. This piece of legislation will be another important element in the reinvigorated road safety framework we are putting in place. We all agree that it is imperative that we have a high level of standards and requirements when it comes to professional qualifications of those that drive heavy goods vehicles (HGVs). The impact of those crashes are very severe. Our rules are already good, but they certainly will be further improved. The agreement we have reached on this proposal certainly brings these necessary changes that will make the regime even more effective. In brief, we are satisfied that in the future our system for professional qualifications will bring the following four key benefits: first, training of professional drivers will have a much stronger road safety dimension to it, with a particular emphasis on how to take care of vulnerable road users; second, the mutual recognition of training across the EU is facilitated for the benefit of drivers and companies; third, the content and organisation of the training will be updated to take into account the ongoing technological developments and new realities such as distraction; and fourth, I also welcome the electronic exchange of information, which will facilitate the mobility of drivers and the enforcement of the training obligations. Congratulations on arriving at such a good compromise and I look forward to a positive vote in the Plenary tomorrow.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President! Commissioner! Drivers' practical skills, their imagination, as well as a quick response to potential hazards increase road safety. And that was a significant objective that we were guided by during the work on the directive on training of professional drivers and driving licences. I want to thank both the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for the level of discussion and openness to arguments, because through this cooperation we have been able to prepare a document that adapts the content of training not only to the needs of drivers but also to the changing solutions technological and new challenges and risks. We have placed great emphasis on practical training supported by classes using information and communication technologies. We have paid attention to protecting the environment through the ability to drive environmentally and raise awareness of the danger posed by using electronic devices while driving. We have addressed the mutual recognition of driver qualifications by Member States by inserting code 95 on the driver's licence document or qualification card. I think an important issue for our constituents is exemption from training duty. But ultimately it will be up to the Member States to decide what entities and what distance they will be excluded from the directive. In conclusion, I think the negotiated text will have a positive impact on the quality and level of skilling of European professional drivers

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President, Commissioner, as rapporteur for the S&D Group on amending the two directives on initial qualification and periodic training of drivers and on driving licences, I would like to stress from the outset cooperation with the rapporteur, the rapporteurs, but also with the Commission. We know it was a vote, but we ended up at the trilogue. After the negotiations and the vote in the TRAN committee of compromises that qualified the European Commission's original proposal, at the trilogue the Commission showed understanding of our proposals and together we managed to convince the Council, which at first disagreed with our point of view. That is why, Commissioner, I want to thank you for the representatives you sent to our negotiation. Regular driver training is extremely important, not only for transport safety, but also for equal treatment in the labour market, in the internal market of workers; we know well that there is mobility of workers. Mutual recognition of qualifications is also important and, let us not forget, it reduces costs, after all, for companies, especially for small companies. I am pleased that the possibility of combining different forms of courses and e-learning, as well as practical courses, was accepted and voted on in the TRAN committee and in plenary, the possibility of combining different forms of courses and e-learning, as well as practical courses, in order to have transport safety and, above all, we had amendments that were accepted in relation to transport training dangerous goods, transport of animals, transport in adverse weather conditions. I also came to the consensus regarding the exemption of some types of transport, and here, personally, I thought especially of those who do not have basic transport activity and who work in rural areas. I want to thank you for your understanding and I believe that this report will bring a plus to the internal transport market.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Mr President, our traffic must be safer. In 2016, 25 670 people crashed on our European roads. That figure has to go down, and well-trained drivers can certainly contribute to that. First of all, vocational training must be adapted to the real risks posed by traffic. Practical lessons on the road must continue to play an essential role in this. In doing so, give Member States the flexibility necessary to determine the content of that training. They can best assess the needs of local road traffic. There must also be an end to the fiddling with false training and certificates. This is a bad practice which has detrimental consequences not only for other road users but also for other operators. Honest hauliers suffer from cowboys who ignore all the rules. With standardisation, additional controls and improved data exchange, we need to tackle these abuses effectively. Today, the European Parliament is sending a strong signal.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (ES) Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank Mr Lundgren for his effort to reach an agreement and the other shadow rapporteurs for the good work he has done. This Directive will improve the training of driving professionals in professional transport and bring it closer to their needs today in a sector that is in profound transformation thanks to the evolution of vehicles, roads and regulations. The incorporation of issues such as driving in extreme weather conditions, environmentally efficient driving or those that need to be developed in particularly congested areas undoubtedly adds safety to roads. In addition, the influence of drivers on the profitability of the service they provide increases. Finally, it will help to equate competition conditions in the internal market. These factors, combined, will improve the social and employment position of these professionals in the transport sector's value chain. Our main objective during the negotiations has therefore been to facilitate ongoing training and retraining processes through technological tools or in-vehicle training processes. At the same time, we want to anticipate the needs of a sector that is already experiencing a real revolution with new information and communications technologies and the emergence of new vehicles with clean propellants and other autonomy and maintenance features. Finally, we regret that we have failed to completely eliminate the derogations which are going to derogate from the scope of this Directive to those carrying out shipments as part of their own business activity in the primary sector on journeys of less than 50 kilometres. Most of these carriages are carried out on secondary roads and on these roads there are generally worse conditions than those of the main networks, combined with the confidence that generates the habit. More training would undoubtedly add road safety in these areas that concentrate more claims due to traffic intensity.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President, first of all, you thank Mr Lundgren for his good cooperation, as well as all the shadow colleagues on this important issue. It is very valuable to have a single EU-wide rules of the game to operate in the driver's profession. These common rules of the game should be considered and updated to reflect the technical and technological developments of the fleet. I consider the reform at hand to be relevant, particularly in terms of road safety and the environment. Road safety requires constant work and awake from us policymakers. Every accident, worst case traffic death, is too much. It is therefore of great importance that we have uniform policies and qualifications for operating in the driver's profession at EU level. This will ensure safe transport from one country to another, regardless of the country in which the driver has received his training. On the theory lesson, I would have wished we had dared to take steps forward. I would have seen it smarter for the EU to look a little more to the future in terms of the use of electronic study environments, e-learning. In particular, in sparsely populated areas with long distances, I believe that electronic theory education should be able to be used more flexibly and more widely in the future.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I never thought I would see the day when I would stand in this Chamber and congratulate our rapporteur. Mr Lundgren has done an excellent job with this report and I thank him for all his hard work. When it comes to HGVs, I cannot think of any Member of this House better qualified for the task.  However, this does not depart from the fact that the CPC Driver Certificate of Professional Competence is a damaging piece of legislation. It has brought misery and hardship to countless drivers in the United Kingdom and across the continent of Europe and I have long campaigned against this unnecessary nonsense. Now that the European Commission has declared that it will not recognise British driving qualifications after Brexit, how short-sighted is that? This surely is an excellent opportunity for Her Majesty’s Government to do the right thing and get shot of the CPC once and for all.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: — Mr. President, the original directive was adopted with the aim of increasing road safety and driver safety, and an additional purpose is to improve the profession of drivers in order to arouse the interest of young people in this profession. The question, however, is how much the proposed amendment to the original directive will actually give the result, and how much additional and unnecessary complication, or unnecessary administrative, financial and time burden on drivers, acting precisely negatively on the achievement of the additional purpose. Neither the report on the implementation of the 2012 directive nor the ex-post impact assessment of 2014 state that as a result of the application of the measures there was an increase in road safety or a decrease in the number of road accidents. It is doubtful the need to train drivers in what they do every day, thus gaining practical experience. Traffic safety on roads would certainly be improved by improving driver conditions, higher quality of vehicles and better checks on their correctness, which we already have regulations. The aspiration to promote the profession is certainly established, but its success depends more on working conditions, working hours, wages, mobility and can be achieved through these forms of regulation before additional training that burden drivers and potentially distract young people from entering into profession. Finally, I believe that it is really necessary to consider once again whether this regulation is necessary at all, whether it achieves its purpose or whether its shortcomings in the form of additional loads for drivers go beyond its potential advantages.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, in a competitive EU market with continuing cross—border services development and a continuous shift towards a digital economy, transport companies often tend to offer more services, but without investing enough on their drivers’ training and skills development or their working conditions. Now there is evidence that this has unfortunately caused more accidents involving trucks on EU roads. The efficiency and safety of the road transport business rely heavily both on the quality of vehicles used and on the skills of the drivers employed by the transportation companies. It also relates to other aspects of the road package, which is why I have tabled separately an amendment to this directive in relation to hired vehicles as drivers need to be aware of the issues around that too. For this reason, the qualification and periodic training of drivers and the ability to verify these skills and enforce the legislation that regulates them across the EU must be regularly updated to match changes. Ensuring the highest possible safety standards is critical, which is why driver training must also focus on protecting vulnerable road users, such as pedestrians, cyclists and persons with limited mobility. In fact, we do need European-wide standards because we need to make sure that we are protecting workers and vulnerable road users across the piece.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: — Mr President, when I look at statistics on victims and injured on the roads in Europe, I no longer think that this is a problem or a catastrophe. This is a war, and I don't think we're winning this war. In this line of thoughts, the training of professional drivers is of the utmost importance and directly affects the road safety of millions of people across Europe. I believe that we should take action as soon as possible, and I welcome the European Commission's latest proposal in this direction. However, I believe that we cannot afford to create additional bureaucracy, additional requirements or financial burdens for the sector, which turns out to be part of the backbone of the European economy and affects and employs millions of citizens. On the other hand, we have to solve several problems: we have to recognise the certificates of qualification in the individual Member States. Otherwise, they lose their meaning. On the other hand, we must make sure that every driver, no matter which Member State of the European Union comes from, meets a minimum of requirements and standards, skills and knowledge, so that we can ensure that they are safely driving the vehicle entrusted to him.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, road safety is, of course, very important. We have thousands of accidents and, as has been said, more than 25 000 people are killed on European roads. But there is one serious issue, Mrs Bulc, which I wanted to raise and that is the qualifications of third-country drivers. We have too many trucks from Turkey circulating in Greece and other European countries. The question is what kind of training do these drivers have and whether they are actually being checked for diplomas or we have several cases where they are monkey diplomas. Finally, I would like to ask you, Mrs Bulc: Judgment C 590/2016 of the Court of Justice on 8/2, which requires the Greek Government to stop allowing duty-free oil to be sold to lorries, mainly Turkish lorries and lorries through duty-free shops third countries. What measures will you take to compel Greece to implement this judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union C 590/2016, dated 8/2/2018?

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for this short but very rich debate. I would once again like to thank the co-legislators for their constructive approach and flexibility shown in reaching this agreement. I am convinced that the end result will contribute to that objective and that it will address the problems we had identified in our proposals. Let me stress here that these new rules will apply to all drivers operating on our roads, including the third countries. This is another important contribution, a step forward towards our vision of zero fatalities and serious injuries on our roads, and I am glad that in May I will be able to present to you our more comprehensive Road Safety Package, which involves the policy orientations for the future, concrete proposals on the infrastructure safety and vehicle safety, as well as a list of other tangible actions that we are working on, including the communication on autonomous mobility. Our next target, in terms of improving the conditions for professional drivers, is already well underway in the discussions on the Road Safety Package, and I look forward to carrying the positive spirit from the Certificate of Professional Competence (CPC) into the next negotiation, and I look forward, as I said before, to a positive vote in plenary tomorrow.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: rapporteur. — Madam President! I believe that we have taken several important steps towards a better form of education, which hopefully will also lead to greater safety on our roads, when drivers receive the training necessary to bring the vehicles safely forward. I would like to be sure to thank all my shadow rapporteurs, who have been very good to cooperate with and have had very constructive proposals. I would also like to thank the Commission, which has been very forthcoming and understood the problems I have pointed out in the report. I would also like to thank the Estonian Presidency, which has also been very constructive in finding a solution.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 13 March 2018. Written declarations (article 162)

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: in writing. — Existing rules on the training of professional drivers are laid down in Directive 2003/59/EC. Following a 2012 evaluation report identified some shortcomings, the Commission proposed a legislative proposal to amend the Directive. The report is recommended to amend the Commission's proposal in several ways. For example, the focus is on efficient driving to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from the transport sector (target to reduce emissions by 20% by 2030 compared to 2008). The opportunities offered by intelligent transport systems to reduce emissions, reduce the accident rate and develop a competitive European transport sector are also recognised. Member States should be provided with opportunities to harmonise their training practices. Such harmonisation should, however, exclude sensitive areas such as driving vehicles for the transport of dangerous goods, heavy goods, animals, etc. Driving licence cards should be issued in the prescribed form in order to ensure mutual recognition. According to the rapporteurs, carriers should be aware of the sources from which they can obtain information on the mandatory laws of the different Member States that affect them. Periodic training with a focus on road safety is required. It also stresses the importance of a network of national cooperation databases to verify the validity of so-called “Certificates of Professional Competence” (CPC).

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the brief presentation of the report by István Ujhelyi on the European Strategy for Cooperative Intelligent Transport Systems (2017/2067 (INI)) (A8-0036/2018).

name: István UJHELYI
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, Dear Colleagues, It's really inspiring to be a rapporter in this house about our future together. However, there is no area for the daily life of a European citizen or guests coming to us, which is not affected by this report, which I have taken care of in the last year and created by shadow-rapporters as a very well, well-coordinated team, which is the intelligent collaboration with each other is about a European strategy for transport systems. A previous speakers mentioned that in 2016 alone, 25 670 Europeans lost their lives in car accidents and 130 000 were injured. A revolutionary change in preventing, avoiding accidents and protecting human life can be the subject that is being discussed and brought to us by the Commission. Similarly, in the everyday life of the organisation of transport, whether we talk about the huge traffic jams on the amazing urban or motorways, or about pollution, it could also be a revolutionary change in the context of the can be implemented in its strategy. And let's add that it can significantly affect our everyday life, whether it's servicing the car, as we are talking about the invention of the nearest food, pizza, cafe. So everything that will be about connecting cars, as passengers, car users and roadside signalling systems in the future, and will later lead us to automatic transport, self-driving systems is somewhere in this strategy. Colleagues, progress and the development of technology are much faster than what we have already done in the European Union in our legislation, strategies or even in our support mechanisms. That is why I use the word once again that this is a revolutionary issue for all of us, how we can implement intelligent transport systems that cooperate with each other. We are talking about the connectivity of 30 million cars per year here in the European Union. Can you imagine what an amazing development, what revolutionary, technological novelty this will be in all of our lives? But let me mention one or two things that I will say that if someone reads the report and deepens it, they may understand better that we also need to deal with the amazing digital gaps in Europe within a region, let alone between countries. And in this report, we also take a long look at who and how the data in vehicles can be accessed, at the time of the development of interoperable transport systems, in whose hands our data file, the amazing amount of data about us, and for what purpose it can be used. Thank you very much to the colleagues who have contributed to my rap police, either in my own secretariat or in other factions as shadow-rapporters. And I have to tell you that we have had over 100 meetings in a year, and I feel that we have the result. If all is true, tomorrow we will be able to adopt this report with a large majority of support and the Commission will continue to work. Thank you very much, Madam President.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: — Mr President, digitalisation, as well as the interactive intelligent transport systems that are talking about in particular, offer really great opportunities to create safer, more efficient, smoother and cleaner transport in the future. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work, as well as the other shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation. In particular, I raise two points from this report. The second concerns the various technologies that we now have at hand. I think it is very good that we chose a technology-neutral approach to this because we must note that the fleet of vehicles is slowly regenerating, and that for a long time to come, we will be in a situation when we have existing vehicles, networked vehicles and potentially wholly self-driving vehicles and all of them need to be able to operate in traffic safely. That is, we need to take an approach where all technologies are able to work together. The second is about access to data. In this day and age, vehicles collect a very large amount of data that is valuable. I am pleased that we have concluded that the Commission wants a proposal by the end of this year on the conditions under which that data will also be accessed by others and thus create innovation.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the transport sector is facing a profound change, to which the European Union must be able to deliver effective answers. Vehicles in use in the European Union are mostly old, produced with technologies that do not allow the application of the most advanced techniques and digital dialogue. Identical observations we can also make for the current road systems, obviously not up to scratch. New technologies, of which cooperative intelligent transport systems are part, require harmonization of legislation, so far confused and with ever-new problems. The delay that the Commission and the European institutions are making clear: the institutional system, in essence, fails to keep pace with the technological revolution, which proceeds at much more speed elevated. There is also the problem of costs: for the introduction of C-ITS services, in order for around 30 million motorists to be connected, about three billion euros per year is required. It is legitimate to ask: who will bear the related costs? And that is why the Member States need to be more involved. We need a shared and effective European strategy. Seizing this challenge is a real and urgent task.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Madam President, the report on the European strategy on cooperative intelligent transport systems, I think, is particularly interesting, as it now faces modern technological challenges, which, of course, if used, could contribute to less traffic jams, environmental protection, no massive pollution, especially on the part of lorries. This means, of course, that we must move forward with a strategy whereby technology must be neutral. We should enable lorry owners and small and medium-sized enterprises to modernize their transport fleet, but that means funds, it means support, because if we automatically move to an arrangement where old vehicles simply go into disuse, you realize that this will leave too many professionals out of work.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: — Dear colleagues, esteemed colleagues, systematic formation of a smart transport system that enables safe, smooth, economically balanced and environmentally friendly movement of people; and goods pose a great challenge to today's society. The European Union seeks to set an example on this, especially if international climate commitments and the internal objectives of the European Union are to be met. I am very pleased that the European global navigation satellite systems Galileo and Egnos, which have now reached such a high level of technological capacity, can help. Moreover, we must not forget that 92% of road accidents are caused by human failure and the use of CITS technologies is important for the effective operation of certain driver assistance systems. The European strategy on cooperating intelligent transport systems has huge potential, but privacy and data protection must come first and be perfectly treated.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: – Madam President, thanks for the innovative work we have done together with this important issue. I think the biggest thing is that we are enabling things to happen. We are enabling legislation. We do not find problems, we find solutions: together, hearing what people are asking for, what their worries are, what kind of problems there are already, and what we need to share. We need to share info, and for that we need all the platforms where we can easily share information, and also where we can share the big data, which is very important with the ICT. When we can share good practice, then we can do good work for the customers and for the environment too, so let’s find solutions with the enabling way.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN), and specifically the rapporteur Mr Ujhelyi, for taking the initiative of putting together this important report. This report could not have come at a better time. This quick deployment of EU-wide interoperable cooperative intelligent transport systems, better known as C-ITS, is the first milestone towards cooperative, connected and autonomous mobility. And cooperative connected an autonomous mobility – and here is yet another abbreviation – CCAM as we call it, is one of the priorities of the third mobility package that is coming out on 2 May this year. Let me pick up on a number of issues in the report that that are of particular importance for our current and future work. The report stresses that the C—ITS communication approach needs to be technology-neutral, based on hybrid communication and interoperable. I couldn’t agree more. As I said in the beginning, rapid deployment is of the essence. The ‘day—one’ services should aim at hitting the mass market in 2019. We must, therefore, build on existing technologies and provide investment security to the early adapters. New technologies such as 5G and satellite will become part of the hybrid communication mix as they become available. But if they are used to provide the same day-one services they must be deployed in a way that is compatible, otherwise the services wouldn’t work properly any more, and, most importantly, we wouldn’t reach our objective of making our transport system safer. I am also very pleased that the report recognises the key coordination role of C-Roads in implementing the C-ITS strategy. Our cooperation with the Member States within C-Roads is indeed instrumental in ensuring that C-ITS services are harmonised across borders. I am therefore proud to announce that the C-Roads family is now expanding to 16 Member States and three third-party countries, including Australia. Finally, I very much welcome the fact that the report mentions data protection and cyber security. Both are indeed required in order to make C—ITS reliable, safe and secure. This is why we intend to cover both areas in a delegated regulation based on the ITS Directive. I hope that we will be able to give you some more details on what to expect in the third mobility package, even if the adoption of the delegated regulation is only foreseen for the end of this year. C-ITS has great potential for all of us, for all of our citizens in terms of road safety and traffic efficiency. I am very pleased to hear and read that this House agrees with me that this is an area calling for EU leadership. I therefore very much welcome the report and look forward to its adoption in plenary tomorrow.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 13 March 2018. Written declarations (article 162)

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. – Currently, we are experiencing an extremely fast—moving technical and digital revolution across all European economy sectors, especially in transport. For policymakers it proves to be a difficult task to keep up with the speed of this rapid development. Therefore, it is important that the EU institutions make substantial efforts to contribute to a common European—wide perspective for the transport sector. Traffic is one of the most significant challenges faced by rapidly growing cites: congested roads are a strain on the environment, the economy and the overall quality of life. For this reason, the EU should encourage and support more research and innovation projects, including the Cooperative Intelligent Transport System (C-ITS) to be able to deal with these problems. Most of all, we should also address the challenges for the C-ITS regarding the guarantee of fair competition in the transport sector and the application of high cybersecurity standards in preventing hacking and cyber-attacks. We should draw our attention to the fact that data protection and confidentiality must be taken into account throughout the processing of data. There is no doubt that the European Strategy on C-ITS is important for the future of the transport sector.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the brief presentation of the report by Michela Giuffrida on lagging behind in development in the European Union (2017/2208 (INI)) (A8-0046//2018).

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to first of all thank you for your support and support when drafting this report on lagging regions development in the European Union. A report highlighting the serious repercussions of the economic and financial crisis which have seriously damaged the growth of these regions: there are 47 in eight Member States, where 83 million live people. The report represents the continuity of a crucial initiative, launched in 2015 by Commissioner Crețu, which aims to bring a better understanding of the complexity of the challenges to which they must coping with these regions, characterized by internal structural weakness which makes them, or at least should make them, the biggest beneficiaries of cohesion policy. The path we took was difficult, because the positions of the various political groups differed widely, but I think we still managed to achieve a very good result, while sacrificing some passages in negotiations, to contemper of course the interest of everyone. We started from the understanding that the macroeconomic framework has a significant impact on regional growth and that the imbalances of the current crisis risk not only weakening economies, but also of to frustrate the spirit of solidarity that characterises the European context and the same principle as cohesion policy, which would thus be minimised its efforts, especially in these regions. We have tried to put to the Commission's attention a number of good practices, which aim to promote and increase growth in these regions, especially with regard to specificity territorial. This is, in my opinion, part of the vindication of our political role, and foreshadows solutions other than those identified by the Commission. If we want to be useful, then, we must overcome the ideological splints in which we are sometimes trapped, and that is why the report outlines three points for achieving this balance, a balance that is likely to be compromised otherwise between politics and economy, between cohesion and economic governance. The real node we have tried to dissolve is the definition of the relationship between cohesion policy and European economic policy, the principle of macroeconomic conditionality which endorses internal symmetries and external regions, and which should be reformed in a positive and constructive perspective in order to encourage and stimulate reforms, with the proper aim of investing in those territories presenting greater structural difficulties. We discuss the relationship between cohesion policy and European semester, which should provide country-specific recommendations as a stimulus to growth and not, on the contrary, in the form of a constraint. We must continue to reiterate and highlight the importance of cohesion policy, an essential tool for correcting imbalances of competitiveness, and which should continue to grant funding ambitious for the benefit of these regions, representing a priority for the European Union. In this context, Member States must play a key role, including by adopting national strategies designed ad hoc for the growth of these regions which are penalised by serious structural deficiencies. As the report states, we must therefore continue to invest in infrastructure and education, expanding and improving relations between businesses and educational institutions. Conditionalities should be focused, before respecting macroeconomic parameters, on respecting the fundamental values of coexistence and solidarity. This is crucial to creating effective European added value for citizens through actions to strengthen economic, social and territorial cohesion, which must always be our objective. In thanking you, and even before I vote in plenary, I await your comments.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, the lagging regions of the European Union, as defined in the relevant Commission report, are an extremely difficult case and need immediate political initiatives. I come from a country, Greece, for which, if you look at the map of the presentation, you will understand that all regions are included in this special category; low income, low growth — and the only way to deal with these problems are specialized strategies — high borrowing costs, limited access to capital for small and medium-sized enterprises, the inability of these regions to have highly trained resources and human capital and unemployment. What can we do? We can intensify efforts in the context of smart specialisation, combine national strategies with regional specific strategies, highlight the competitive advantages of these regions, support entrepreneurship at institutional level through smart productive, even state aid, and above all to make use of cohesion policy. It's the only way to stop the growth downhill.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, macroeconomic imbalances caused by the crisis risk frustrating decades of efforts implemented with cohesion policy, particularly in low-growth regions and where worrying levels of public and private debt prevent its development. In the difficult relationship between cohesion policy and European economic policy, it is necessary that macroeconomic conditionality, which should bind cohesion funds to compliance with governance rules European economic, is declined exclusively in a positive perspective, in order to encourage and stimulate reforms, with the aim of investing in territories with greater structural difficulties. The need for Member States to play a fundamental role for a better decline in cohesion policy instruments is increasingly evident, by adopting strategies in cooperation with the Commission national for the growth of lagging regions, penalised by even serious structural deficiencies, investing massively in infrastructure, but also in education, and exploiting the potential of activities traditional ones that contribute to defining territorial identity.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the interventions that need to be made to support the regions that are lagging behind are specific, we all know them. It is a matter of political will and of course resources. Greece is a country whose regions are lagging behind almost all. We have a great many problems, which have also been intensified because of the memorandum policy. However, Mrs Crețu, I would like to refer to a specific issue concerning the islands of Lesvos, Chios, Samos, Ikaria and Leros, which have been regulated by the end of July 2018 to maintain low value added tax. It is an arrangement that has always been in force, and these islands have been chosen to be excluded, because they have enormous problems due to migration flows. The point is, however, that this exception must continue for all the Aegean islands, in other words to have a low value added tax, so that they can move on to development. It's something you need to consider.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the report on so-called regions lagging behind development contains several positive indications, but also some critical issues. Positive is the highlighting of the need for a genuinely supportive approach in the context of the migration challenge, in the absence of which the contribution of cohesion funds, which in itself should not be be destined for immigration, it won't be effective. Positive is to highlight the extremely negative effects of the economic crisis and the related cuts imposed by the Stability Pact, as well as the proposal to assess the impact of excluding co-financing national and regional structural funds from the calculation of the deficit would have on public investment. However, we cannot agree with an approach that is too timid and different from the initial draft on structural reforms. It is not possible to say that reforms can help Member States and regions achieve better results if the Commission does not first clarify their purpose and definition. Due to opposition from a majority of other groups, there is no mention of the danger of the Commission's proposal to use the performance reserve — 21 billion — to allocate these resources to privatisation or precarization interventions of the labour market.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the report on the so-called lagging regions of the European Union shows a virtual reality of supposedly problematic exceptions — including Greece — in an otherwise prosperous European Union. But the tale of so-called convergence, which you have projected for years, has gone bankrupt. Your cohesion policy is the jungle that workers already live across the European Union. It is subsidies, all the workers' sweat, for the profits of business groups, provided the harsh anti-labour measures in the name of development. In the report, you consider collective bargaining as provocatively stiffness, that is, you even target the suspicion of signing a collective agreement. Your criteria are the European Semester and the Stability Pact, the memoranda of lasting duration of the European Union and the governments, which are foreseen after the formal exit from the Memoranda. In the 88 new sacrifices - prerequisites of the fourth evaluation, workers in Greece with their rallies on the 20th of the month respond and claim collective agreements with increases in wages and improvement of working conditions.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: Madam President, I would just like to underline the rapporteur's commitment effort and, in particular, the fact that she has approached the ideas put forward by the PPE with regard to policies aimed at less developed regions and the future of the European Semester. The rapporteur has therefore approved, in the Committee on Regi, a very balanced and far-reaching report, but, at the same time, affirmative, which clearly expresses the European Parliament's position on the strategy for regions with lower growth or lower incomes in our Union, or that is, to less developed regions. From the content of the report, and in addition to the inclusion of the proposal to create a system of positive incentives for the post-2020 period, I would highlight two more of our proposals, which are the idea of the need for ambitious funding for cohesion policy, rather than the initial expression 'adequate funding ”, and the idea that specific programmes, strategies and action plans should be created, that is, tailor-made for these regions through participatory and multilevel governance, in order to stimulate more effectively employment and growth and sustainable development of the regions.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: — Madam President, there are large gaps in the European Union in terms of revenues and opportunities for regions. 47 regions in 8 Member States were qualified either low-growth or low-income regions, differentiating from GDP per capita. In many of these regions, agriculture remains an important economic factor and a key source of income. That is why the Common Agricultural Policy is an essential financing instrument for boosting growth and making an important contribution to boosting sustainable growth, creating jobs, while contributing to the preservation of rural areas and combating depopulation of rural areas. Rural development funds are also of particular importance in boosting the competitiveness of these regions, through tailor-made projects based on bottom-up approaches. I therefore consider important and welcome the contribution of local action groups in developing local strategies, supporting stakeholder networking and validating and approving individual LEADER projects.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, today's report shows a reality - we have, and it is good that we recognise, less developed regions. We even have poor regions, if we were to be honest. What needs to be done? I believe that the report has shown important lines, which we must follow, but I believe that today's conclusion, after the debate on the report, and I hope it will also be voted on, is that we must preserve the cohesion funds beyond 2020.
