We have not ended up without disparities in the European Union, we have poor population, we have rural areas where per capita income is very low. The responsibility, of course, is very high - of Member States, regional officials and local administration - but I believe that, as an example of good practice, what you are already doing, Commissioner, must continue, so that we can create the same living conditions in the European area.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Madam President, the lagging regions do not need alms nor want to be parasites who will unplan to spend the money of other people's taxpayers. Of the more developed ones, they primarily need knowledge and best practices on the basis of which they will develop independently in the direction in which their residents want. The necessary infrastructure projects as the basis of new growth can be financed through the Union's cohesion policy and that is why it is very important that we preserve it in its current form and beyond 2020. The key recommendation in this report is the specialization of strategies for specific regions as their needs and challenges vary. Universal solutions, as a rule, do not give good results and I am glad that we finally recognized it. This initiative is focused on 47 regions in eight countries, among which there is no Croatia. As some parts of our state also face rapid youth leaving, falling incomes and rising poverty, I ask, Mrs. Crețu, that they should be included in this list when defining regions that are lagging behind at NUTS III level.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: — Madam President, low-growth or low-income regions should not be seen as a burden on Member States or on the European Union. On the contrary, cohesion policy has a very important role to play in giving precisely these regions and their citizens the opportunity to become more competitive, more prosperous, from which everyone will gain. For this reason, I strongly believe that cohesion policy must be maintained in the current format and with the current budget in the new Multiannual Financial Framework. In my country, we continue to see injustices and expanding scissors between the capital and almost all other regions and cities. To do this, it is necessary for the state to stand behind the people of these regions, becoming a guarantor and stimulator for low-interest loans and investments: investments in digital infrastructure, investment in the future and new opportunities. There will be no two-speed Europe when there are no two-speed countries either.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, regions with significant development gaps and low income regions face common challenges, namely lower productivity, employment and school attendance rates than in other regions. Also, the steady decline in rural population, mainly caused by the migration of young people and skilled labour to more attractive regions, has generated mainly an acute shortage of workers in the agricultural sector. I believe that bridging existing gaps involves supporting measures to increase connectivity, increase access to outlets, provide basic services in rural regions, as well as professional and financial advisory services. At the same time, policies focused on attracting young people to agriculture must be developed, while prioritizing investments in basic infrastructure. However, I draw attention to the consequences that Brexit may have on regions lagging behind, as possible cuts in funding will have devastating effects due to the vulnerabilities faced by these areas.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, dear rapporteur Michela Giuffrida, first of all I would like to congratulate you as rapporteur, but also the Members of the Committee on Regional Development (REGI) for this initiative on this report. The discussion I heard here in Parliament is very meaningful to me. Firstly, because most of you know that lagging regions were one of my top priorities since I became Commissioner so I think it is very important to underline that in the Treaty we have this goal to fill the gaps to reduce disparities, and that is why we are creating these studies on lagging regions to see why so many regions are still stagnating despite the economic growth, despite the fact that we have lower unemployment. We still have regions which are not growing and we do not see results in creating jobs and growth.  I very much welcome the main finding of these reports. It favourably echoes what the Commission strives to underline in its own report on lagging regions and, after listening to the debate, I think overall we share the same views that the social and economic situation of these lagging regions is multi—faceted. It cannot be addressed through a one—size—fits—all policy. On the contrary, as you said here, it requires regionally—differentiated investments and policy responses.  This is why, as you know, in the analysis carried out, two groups of lagging regions were identified: low-income regions, mostly in the eastern periphery of the European Union, and low-growth regions in southern Europe. The pilot project we launched in parallel to complement the analytical strength, namely in test regions in Poland and in Romania, have allowed us to propose hands-on solutions to tackle structural bottlenecks. In Poland, the ‘Catching Up’ region initiative has helped, for example, to improve the conditions for starting a business, the management of financial instruments, or special planning practices. In Romania, tailor—made specialisation strategies and action plans were elaborated, as well as project pipelines in sectors like biomedicine or agro—food.  I have followed closely all the discussions REGI Committee on our report and on the results of the pilot project. I know that there was a heated debate on our recommendation to strengthen the link between European Structural and Investment Funds and the European Semester. I understand very well that some of you may think that we are demanding too much but, on the other hand, we all know that challenges in the quality of governance hinder the performance of public investments. So if we manage to ensure a link with the European Semester, which is more proportionate and more operational, I believe it will help foster the essential structural changes in the areas which have been targeted with our pilot actions, such as business environment, innovation ecosystems, vocational education or training.  This also means going towards a structural reform system based on incentives. For the next Multiannual Financial Framework we are reflecting on a mechanism which would provide positive incentives to the Member States. In the meantime, the work continues. The pilot actions tested in some regions, as I said, will be extended this year to other regions of both countries and in other countries. I fully agree with you that we need more cohesion than ever because, as I said, reducing disparities is our main goal. To the idea that you raised, I do not need to underline once again my support for the equal development of all the regions. I fully agree that we are side by side with all the regions. We were with the island of Lesbos, with Madeira, after the earthquake in Italy, so we are with the Solidarity Fund wherever it is needed. You raised a point about EMU and taxes which is not under my responsibility, but I stand ready to come to Parliament every time to provide information on the outcome of the actions we have on the ground everywhere in Europe in all the 290 regions.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 13 March 2018. Written declarations (article 162)

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. - I believe that cohesion policy must play a key role in promoting the harmonious development of the Union as a whole by reducing the disparities between the levels of development of the different regions. Most of Romania's territory is among the 47 remaining regions identified in the European Commission's report. In order to ensure the development of these areas, specific measures and programmes are needed, adapted for each region, taking into account sub-regional trends and disparities. In this respect, the European Commission must abandon the imposition of macroeconomic conditionality and structural reforms, and GDP per capita must continue to remain the main indicator for the allocation of funds under cohesion policy, given that regions with developmental delays already face difficulties in accessing finance, as well as bureaucratic and administrative delays preventing the absorption of EU funds.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. — Cohesion policy — implemented through the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund (ESF) and the Cohesion Fund — is the European Union's main policy on investment, growth and development. It aims to reduce economic, social and territorial disparities between Community regions. It is particularly important that cohesion policy materialises one of the most fundamental values of the European Union, which is European solidarity. On the eve of the start of negotiations on the next multiannual EU financial framework, it should be emphasised with all firmness that cohesion policy should continue to be a priority of the Union and be adequately supported by ambitious funding, even in the light of the pressure on the EU budget. Cohesion policy is the main tool of European economic policy for public and private investment taking into account the territorial, social and economic specificity of regions.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. — Known is that there are regions in the EU with late development (i.e. 'low growth regions' and 'low income regions') due to the negative impact on regional economic growth of the protracted economic and financial crisis. This is the case even though cohesion policy has contributed about a third of the EU budget to foster growth and employment and reduce disparities between EU regions. In this context, an analysis of regional and national co-financing under the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds) and its impact on national deficits is necessary. Late development regions are often characterized by a lack of structural reforms, economic stagnation is caused by a decrease in public and private investment. We also agree that these regions often face the exodus of young people and skilled labour, both of which are necessary for the economic and social revitalisation of those areas, making these regions even less attractive in what concerns employment and investment.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the brief presentation of the report by Ángela Vallina on the role of EU regions and cities in the implementation of the Paris Agreement of COP 21 on climate change (2017/2006 (INI)) (A8—0045/2018).

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, Commissioner, climate change is an uncontestable evidence and an already everyday reality. And we are witnessing an increase in extreme temperatures, forest fires, droughts, floods and storms, as well as the proliferation of invasive alien species and the loss of biodiversity, and, on the other hand, competition for water and energy demand. Evidence on human responsibility for climate change is beyond doubt and already has devastating environmental effects and high socio-economic costs, especially on the most vulnerable populations. Climate change is also accentuating social disparities throughout our Union. Some social groups are more exposed than others because of poor health, low income, inadequate housing, lack of mobility or gender issues, among other factors. But the entire public is already suffering serious health problems due to pollution, cancers, allergies, premature deaths, etc. A real social drama that also involves tremendous health costs. The money we do not spend on investing to correct the problem is then multiplied in health spending. That is why my report deplores, first of all, the withdrawal of the United States from the Paris Agreement and presents alternatives and responses from the perspective of the role of cities and municipalities in the fight against climate change. The European Union has a lot of work ahead and contributes — it must be said — with 9% of global emissions and its cities generate 75% of them. More than 70% of Europeans and 73% of jobs are found in urban areas. Cities have a great responsibility for global warming and at the same time they are a great potential for solutions. How can it be otherwise, I really want to thank you for the effort by the other MEPs, shadow rapporteurs, reaching a majority consensus among all political groups. There has been a lot of teamwork, in which several experts in this field have participated and in which we have gathered an important social demand: putting on the political agenda the fight against climate change, once again and forcefully. The report can be a real political benchmark on what the role of European regions and cities should be in climate change. I also call on all Members of this House to vote in favour tomorrow and therefore the European Parliament will take an important step on the issue of global warming. It would be a real and definitive step in the fight against warming. We must not forget that the European Parliament represents the voice of citizenship, and in this report it emphasizes the urgency and extreme importance of combating global warming. This requires the European Commission to take up and take up the proposals in this report, although sometimes I, as a Spaniard, have to deeply regret that precisely the Commissioner for Climate Action and Energy, Mr Arias Cañete, is known in my country for the measures against renewable energies in our country. You know this well: sun tax, etc. And, if that were not enough, the Government of Spain has been practicing a policy of cuts in competences and economic resources to local authorities for years, unacceptably limiting its capacity to implement measures against global warming. It is time for us to assume the political responsibility entrusted to us by the public. Let's not stay in half inks. Let's take forceful action. And that is why I would like this report to go ahead tomorrow, and with that very important amendment which has been tabled separately.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, as shadow rapporteur on behalf of the European People's Party on this report, I would like to thank the rapporteur and remind the House that 359 million European citizens, almost 72.5% of the population of the European Union, live in cities. The effects of climate change, extreme weather conditions, storms, floods, droughts and soil erosion are visible there. In my country, Greece, we had 23 deaths some time ago, following disastrous floods. This catastrophe could have been avoided if there were proper planning and appropriate infrastructure. It is therefore necessary to listen to local government, to encourage investment in cities, in energy efficiency, in innovation for clean energy sources and in renewable energy sources, but also in infrastructure projects. We must, now that resources are being reduced, try to have the use of the additional financial instruments from the European Fund for Strategic Investments, as well as from Connecting Europe Facility and from Horizon 2020.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: — Madam President, today one of the biggest challenges facing humanity in terms of sustainable development, health and the world economy is the global warming process. Without the involvement of all actors at local and regional level, States will not be able to fulfil their commitments under COP 21. The credibility of the commitments made by the parties will depend on the real and firm involvement of cities and regions, as well as businesses and investors. In this context, I believe that the European Union and the Member States must pay greater attention to the Convention of Mayors, while maintaining this kind of long-term cooperation, until 2030 or even 2050, in order to stimulate the dynamic of the 6 500 European signatory cities and regions, which have committed meet the European Union's 2020 greenhouse gas emission reduction targets and even exceed them. On the other hand, it should be emphasised that regions and cities involved in the implementation of COP 21 need determined and innovative investments that focus on sustainable projects, especially in the field of energy... (the speaker was interrupted by the President)

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Madam President, the role of regions and cities is particularly important in implementing the Paris agreement, COP 21 on climate change, and of course this applies to the whole of Europe, it also concerns Greece, where unfortunately there is no cooperation between central administration and local government and in the regions. We have seen that we have had huge natural disasters recently in Mandra, with 23 deaths, and so far the local government is still protesting about the famous work being done. This applies to the whole of Greece. The additional element that we need to take seriously, and it has to do with Greece again, is that it has entered into a process, due to the memorandum options, which includes the privatization and sale of DESFA, DEPA, HELPE and mainly PPC units. There can be no policy of supporting the environment when these massive privatisation takes place.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, implementing the COP 21 objectives must be a joint effort at all levels; therefore, cities and local authorities have a great role to play. In Greater Manchester – in my constituency – the Labour Mayor, Andy Burnham, is holding a Green Summit on 21 March, as part of an initiative to make Manchester the greenest city in Europe. Manchester vote to remain, by the way. The Green Summit follows extensive stakeholder consultation and brings together environmental experts, interest groups, partner agencies, academics and local people to accelerate Greater Manchester’s green ambitions. Young people are absolutely key to tackling climate changed, as proved by the Eco Group from St Christopher’s High School in Accrington, also in my constituency. These informed, passionate and creative young people are the leaders of the future. They came to the European Parliament for Child Rights Day in November and met with Michel Barnier’s Brexit team. They know that the UK cannot tackle climate change alone. The fight against climate change is a global challenge that we must keep fighting together with our European partners.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Madam President, Indeed, the role of regions and cities in curbing emissions and combating climate change is extremely important. At the same time, we must not go by the fact that, although 75% of the European population say they are urban residents, more, 44% of people are tied to agriculture in one way or another. Therefore, we must see that agriculture is, in itself, the largest individual emitters of pollution in Europe. So I think that we can all consider and take to heart the so-called “smart villages” concept, the essence of which, in the middle of the idea, is precisely environmental protection, and techniques that protect our environment in general and enable precision agriculture.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, I do not know if this is the way it was meant to be, but the report comes very well after the other report being debated. The role of regions and cities in implementing the Paris agreement cannot be challenged, just as we cannot challenge climate change. Citizens, after all, are suffering the consequences of climate change. That is why I believe that emphasis should be placed on environmental protection education. It has been said here, of course, that local governments and regions are needed and have an important role, but I believe that there should be special budget chapters for citizens' education. On the other hand, the education system must contain knowledge about global warming, about climate change. Without a citizens' education, we will not be able to achieve very good results. The use of renewable energies is just one of the many measures to be taken. We have others - afforestation, a ban on felling forests are indispensable measures. Then innovation and research are needed to have clean technologies. This is why I see the connection with the development of poorer regions, because there is also the violation, the possible violation, of the Paris agreement.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, Madam rapporteur, honourable Members, on behalf of the Commission I would like to thank you all at the European Parliament for preparing this important report. When I say important, I mean mostly politically important, because it calls for further mobilisation in the battle against climate change and because it puts some national actors on the front line, of course alongside the Member States. This is, indeed, where regions and cities should be when it comes to finding solutions for climate change mitigation and adaptation. They have proved to be ambitious, forward-looking and innovative, so we need all of them on board. This is why is the Commission welcomes Parliament’s call to national governments to further support climate and energy initiatives at local and national level. It mirrors the efforts made at European level to ensure that low carbon and climate-resilient targets are well embedded in all our policies. As a matter of fact, it seems these efforts have paid off. Climate mainstreaming: the target of at least 20% of the EU budget has helped us to deliver on the Paris Agreement and on our climate and energy objectives. For instance, in the 2014-2020 programming period, close to 25% of the European Structural and Investment Funds will be dedicated to climate-related actions such as energy efficiency, renewables and water retention measures. We take good note of your call for the next Multiannual Financial Framework to be even more ambitious in achieving the objectives of the Paris Agreement. I can assure you, on behalf of the Commission, that we will do our utmost to ensure that projects financed by the EU budget are in line with these objectives. There will be no place for ‘business as usual’. In the meantime, the Commission will continue to support cities and regions through the several ongoing initiatives. I have in mind, for example, the EU Covenant of Mayors, which has been contributing to our climate and energy objectives since 2008. Indeed, EU Covenant cities have already reduced their emissions by 23% and have pledged to reach –27% by the year 2020. I also have in mind the Urban Agenda for the European Union, which was mentioned here by Ms Spyraki and other honourable Members of the European Parliament. As you may know, twelve partnerships have been put in place under the Urban Agenda, including on climate adaptation and energy transition. Here, cities, regions, Member States and the European institutions are currently working together on action plans to improve legislation, increase knowledge and use European funds more effectively in this area. I had the pleasure, for instance, Ms Ward, to meet the mayor of Manchester last week, and I was very impressed by his pro-European approach and by his active enthusiastic work, hand-in-hand, alongside other cities. Congratulations to all the cities. I think it is very important. He was present at another initiative we had last week on regions in transition, and Manchester was selected as one of these industrial transitions. To conclude, I would like to mention that this year is the year of so-called Talanoa Dialogue. This word is from Fiji, describing an inclusive and open exchange, and, in preparation for the next UN Climate Conference (COP24), which will take place in Poland in December, local and regional authorities have this opportunity to share their successful policies and good practices through this Talanoa Dialogue. I encourage all stakeholders to use this platform, and I think it will be a valuable contribution to our collective work. Thank you to Ms Vallina for this report and thank you for your views and for your attention.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 13 March 2018. Written declarations (article 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — Cities have a huge responsibility for global warming and therefore can potentially play a leading role in fighting it. Clean energy innovations and small-scale renewable energy projects are key in achieving the goals of the COP 21 Paris Agreement. This, together with a truly sustainable and more generally sustainable local public transport, an awareness and proper and complete information of citizenship of the importance of the consequences of climate change. The proposal then recalls, and is central, the opportunity to consider reducing greenhouse gas emissions, remediation work and activities aimed at regenerating and decontaminating polluted industrial sites as an important element in the evaluation of the performance of the Operational Programmes envisaged under the cohesion policy.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the one-minute speeches on important political issues (rule 163 of the rules of procedure).

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: — Madam President, as a citizen of the Slovak Republic, I would like to comment on the situation in Slovakia. I would like to draw your attention to the fact that citizens of the Slovak Republic today have more confidence in the institutions of the European Union than in the Slovak Republic. This is a serious crisis of confidence, especially towards the Government of the Slovak Republic. Attention, however: after sending a delegation of MEPs to Slovakia, some of the citizens of Slovakia think that with this step we have also taken responsibility for future developments in the country. The basis of the events is very deep corruption, as well as corruption in relation to European Union funds. I would like to draw attention to this moment and ask those responsible for the European Commission and OLAF to address this issue sufficiently intensively. Of course, the murder of a journalist must be investigated under international supervision, as soon as possible.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: — Madam President, I would like to draw the attention of my colleagues to the events foreseen under Article 17 of the Treaty. This article organizes the dialogue, which is supposed to be open and transparent, between our institutions, on the one hand, and faith-based organizations, on the other, but also philosophical and non-denominational organizations. I stress these because they are increasingly marginalised in this Parliament. I note with concern that defenders of humanism, free thought and freedom of conscience are very rarely invited to intervene in these events, whereas, at the same time, there are numerous gatherings where representatives of the three major monotheisms are asked to comment on the Union's foreign policy. This is all the more problematic given that religions are sometimes used in some of the States concerned to oppress or even persecute populations. Of course I am thinking of women, sexual minorities, but also atheists and apostates, who can risk their lives simply by this fact. Our values of peace, freedom, equality, do not need the model of faith to be integrated. Sometimes they can even be fought by the most extreme forms of all religions. That is why I solemnly call for this Parliament to stop giving priority to religious hierarchies and strive to guarantee everyone's freedom of conscience.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: — (start of speech when the microphone is off)... Do you know what that is? These are iodine tablets. Belgium has bought 45 million of them so that the citizens of the country can better protect themselves from radioactive radiation in the event of a nuclear accident. Precautionary measure? The crumbling nuclear power plant in Tihange speaks another language: finger-thick cracks in the reactor, more and more incidents, hardly any dialogue with neighbouring countries, no cross-border civil protection concept. And that's when Belgium only prescribes iodine against the marody miler. With all due respect, these pills are a sedative for the bin. I appeal to the Belgian government, together with my free voters in North Rhine-Westphalia and Rhineland-Palatinate, together with millions of citizens in the border triangle: close Tihange, right now! I appeal to the Commission: put pressure on the Belgian Government, in the name of security! I appeal to the German government: stop silence! Off for Tihange! Again, stop Tihange now before it's too late!

name: Thierry CORNILLET
text: — Madam President, the principle of transnational lists in the forthcoming European elections has been rejected by Parliament. This is a missed opportunity to bring about a transnational debate that would have been disjointed from our national debates. It is also a missed opportunity to highlight a symbol, the one that the Union is a whole and not just the addition of countries. We may not stay here. Let's take advantage of the fact that European citizens will be called on in May 2019 to choose their representatives to add to this election a popular consultation on our common future. This consultation could take the form of a question or proposal answered “yes” or “no” and would be the subject of a second vote at the same time, on the same day, in a second ballot box devoted to it. Thus all European citizens could be consulted and, I believe, collectively, would be at heart to answer a question about their common future. I therefore propose that Parliament should be on the initiative and that the subject of this consultation or this issue be discussed in the first place in our Chamber.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: Madam President, my first speech as an MEP in this part of the plenary is in support of popular movements in the defence of pensions, housing, public health, school, equality and freedom of expression. Movements in defense of democracy. In the case of Galicia and the Spanish State, the popular movements arise because of passivity and against the structural reforms of the People's Party, which aim to level down present and future living conditions. About pensions, do you know what Mr. Rajoy's government is doing? A rise in misery, lying, because the spending to maintain the system is less than spent in the EU as a whole, so the effort could be increased if there was political will. The differences between men and women are also large and, in the case of Galicia, pensions are the lowest in the state. And do you know what the social response is? A revolution of grandparents who took to the streets demanding decent pensions. Another movement is that of housing, today present here. The platform of affected by mortgages, awarded in this Parliament, wants to discuss the housing law in the European Parliament, and the People's Party does not allow it.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Madam President, the abduction of Greek military troops by the Turkish military police on the border of Evros on 1 March and their continued hostage hijacking since then constitutes a further escalation in the aggression of the Turkish regime towards Member States of the Union, such as Greece and Cyprus. They were preceded by the pirate obstruction of the drilling rig in the Cypriot EEZ, the embolism of the Greek port ship and others. These actions by Turkey, coupled with the invasion of Turkish troops into Syria and the siege of the city of Afrin violate international law and prove that the country has no intention of fulfilling even the elementary obligations arising from its status as a candidate state for membership of the Union. It is necessary to suspend the payment of pre-accession financial assistance to Turkey and to ban the export of European weapons systems used against civilians.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: — Madam President, today I will present to you the message received from a European citizen named Florin Coman and is a student in Gorj County, Romania, who is concerned about the education situation and lack of vocational schools. I quote: “Everyone blames young people for the way the country goes. We're told we're lazy, millennials, snowflakes, and I know how. But is it our fault that we are like this? Not all of us are born into elite families, and we are not all geniuses. What opportunities does the country offer us? We are going through Europe to do unskilled work because at home we have only one and one faculties, but also vocational schools. Parents push their children to go to college to be among the world, but they also get to work from below. I would like to know why you, the leaders of the country and of Europe, do not recognise the gaps in education and treat them with the real needs that we have?” I ended the quote. I hope to receive and make more and more such messages heard, because we must remember that the European Union is for and about its citizens.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Madam President! The representatives of the Szekler autonomy movement and the organizers and participants of the Szekler Freedom Day organized by the Szekler National Council have been subjected to official harassment, retaliation and sanctions from the outset. One of the most recent flagrant cases of this is the expulsion of Attila Dabis, the Foreign Affairs Representative of the SZNT from Romania without justification. The deprivation of rights, reminiscent of the Ceausescu times, contradicts the laws of Romania and violates the fundamental principle of freedom of movement of European citizens. I object to his ban without a court order and his declaration as an unwanted person, since Attila Dabis has committed nothing illegal, but only defends the rights and interests of the Hungarian national community in Romania.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for sitting here at such a late hour in Parliament, listening to our political statements and, I hope, you will also carry the message. I would like to speak, for the last time, in my political statement, about the Treaty provision on free movement of workers, about the equal treatment of European citizens. But do these things actually happen? Last week I went to Graz, Austria, in my car, from the city of Timișoara, located in the western part of Romania. We could see queues of tens of kilometres of trucks waiting at the border control at the entrance to Hungary, then at the entrance to Austria. Citizens and transport companies in my country are discriminated against, drivers stay days or even weeks and sleep in the cab. On the other hand, we are discussing here, in the European Parliament, and countries like Germany, France and Belgium are fining drivers sleeping in the parking lot. But is staying in the frontier for a week and sleeping in the cabin better social conditions? I think we need to get an answer and I want to know why Romania is not in Schengen, although, for years, it has been technically observing all the conditions? Is it just political marginalization?

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, for 13 years Macedonia has been blocked on its EU path because of the name issue with Greece – 13 wasted years. Why? Well, apparently there is a problem because there is the country of Macedonia and the province of Macedonia in Greece. Is that really a problem? As far as I know, there is a province of Luxembourg and the country of Luxembourg. No problems. There is the state of Azerbaijan and the region of Azerbaijan in Iran. There is Georgia in the USA and Georgia on the outskirts of the EU. Nobody makes a problem out of it. So is this really a problem? No, nobody cares. The problem is that we allow one Member State to block accession countries and that we tolerate these expressions of nationalism. I am aware how sensitive this issue is, but we have neither the energy nor the time for these almost childish name games. So please let us stop it.

name: Miroslavs MITROFANOVS
text: – Madam President, on Saturday, 10 March, a protest rally was held in Riga, the capital of Latvia. Five thousand participants expressed their deep concern regarding the decision of the Latvian authorities to destroy the system of minority education. I promised to inform the EU institutions about this disaster. Thirteen years ago, when Latvia joined the EU, the Latvian authorities agreed and incurred obligations to respect and protect national minorities. The recent decision to prohibit the use of minority languages as a tool of instruction in secondary schools is a flagrant violation of these basic principles of the EU. The Russian—speaking minority of Latvia comprises up to 40% of the population of the country. The ongoing destruction of Russian minority schools undermines the peace and mutual confidence in the society. On behalf of my voters and on behalf of the Russian minority in Latvia, I ask the EU institutions to intervene in this situation and ensure the protection of human rights in Latvia. Let us say it together: stop killing minority schools.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Madam President, there are currently at least three million empty homes in Spain. Meanwhile, the number of evictions remains unbearable: one eviction every eight minutes. They are two sides of the speculative economic development on which the Spanish economy has been based, an economic model that has depreached our territory and directly violated the basic rights of the population, such as the right to housing. Meanwhile, self-organized social movements, such as the Platform for Affected by the Mortgage, have been fighting for the most basic social rights for years. The Spanish government has always preferred to rescue banks rather than families and now wants to veto even the possibility of debating the legislative initiative presented by the PAH at parliamentary headquarters. From Europe we want to show our rejection of the PP Government's attempt to suspend democracy by avoiding even debating the proposals of the PAH, to which we want to show our full support from the European Parliament. To them, to their proposals, to their struggle and to their initiative.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: — Madam President, on the occasion of 8 March, we are accustomed to highlighting the skills of women, their professional and sporting performance, and we call for the removal of obstacles that prevent women from realising their potential and talents. But while women also have an irreplaceable role as mothers, although the future of Europe and the world depends on them in the most consistent sense of the word, to mention this fact means exposing themselves to accusations of spreading stereotypes. In 2010, even a report by the Council of Europe's Equal Opportunities Committee called the portrayal of women in the media as mothers as stereotypical as depicting them as passive and inferior beings or sexual objects. Motherhood is not a stereotype, but a privilege, responsibility and performance at the same time. International Women's Day should proudly remind the whole world of this.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Madam President, Anglian Water have 4.3 million customers. They generate GBP 1.2 billion in revenue and last year paid out GBP 320 million to their shareholders. Anglian Water sounds quite profitable to me but the company, with a subsidiary in the Cayman Islands, had a corporation tax bill of zero. Not a single penny to help fund our vital public services. And now they want to replace their pension scheme with one that’s a lot worse for their workers. Local staff who have contacted me are rightly angry. I am of the firm belief that Anglian Water can well afford to pay for their staff’s pensions. It is a drop in the ocean for them. And so my message to them is clear: don’t water down your work force’s pensions. Think again – you have the power to stop this tidal wave of anger from your workers.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: Madam President, I denounce this again: this House rightly condemns human rights attacks on all parts of the planet, some almost unknown even to us. But this same House has been unable to consider the aggressions on human rights and democratic principles that are constantly being committed in Spain against Catalans. After democratic elections won by the independence forces, the Spanish Government does not accept the result and instructs a judge to decide who should be president of the Government of Catalonia. That would be a major scandal in any other state and is a scandal for any first-grade law student. While in Spain and other European countries the far right is moving forward without a brake, this House is quiet. We Catalans are in favour of a Europe of freedom, rights and justice; the rest is despicable to us. I hope that one day this Parliament will wake up ashamed: that it is not too late.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, this Parliament is debating what the EU relationship with Britain will be post—Brexit. For most people, Brexit is undefined, negotiated by the unprepared, seeking unspecified outcomes which will end in an unmitigated disaster for the people of Ireland. So, if the British Government refuses to live up to its commitments on the border of Ireland and on no diminution of our rights, the Brexit negotiations should freeze. The British Government’s rejection in March of what they agreed in December is an absolute scandal but, you know, it is not new. Those of us who are used to negotiating with the British know only too well how hard it is to hold them to their commitments. They claim to support the Good Friday Agreement in all of its parts, they say there will be no denial of our rights, they say that they do not want a hard border but, from where we are standing, it looks like they are designing the uniform, training the dogs and sharpening the razor wires.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: — Madam President, on 1 March two Greek soldiers allegedly crossed the border between Greece and Turkey and entered Turkish territory, in the region of Thrace, which is also a border of Europe. Such incidents have occurred before by both countries and have always been resolved within hours, at an administrative level. In this case, however, the soldiers were arrested, handcuffed and covered persons as criminals to the courts of Edirne and subsequently to the maximum security prisons, where they are illegally detained, without being charged. This serious incident adds to Turkey's systematic aggression against Greece, deliberate disregard for the rule of law and the conscious questioning of international law. The European Union must, here and now, react to Turkey's extreme aggression against its Member State. We demand that President Erdogan be forced to maintain good neighbourly relations so that the Greek soldiers can return to Greece immediately.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: Madam President, a few days ago we had confirmation that the Trump Administration decided to impose tariffs on aluminum and steel, also on Europeans, on security grounds. Certainly claiming security reasons regarding a partner, such as Europe, is one more of the crazy ideas that the Trump Administration is teaching us in recent times. In my region, in Asturias, we have very important companies in both steel and aluminum, companies that may be harmed by this protectionist threat from the Trump Administration, not so much because we export a large amount to the United States, but because of the possible effect of trade diversion of those tariffs. I therefore support the firm response, the rapid response of the European Commission and demand that this European Parliament follow the activity of the Trump Administration very closely. Many believe in good transatlantic relations. Let us hope that this decision will have a clear response from Europe.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, today it is exactly nineteen years since NATO's eastward enlargement took place. Therefore, Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic joined NATO on 12 March 1999. For the first time in the separate history of these states, they received real security guarantees and could also contribute to the collective security protection of the democratic world. But what I am watching with concern is that NATO is being politically weakened on both sides of the Atlantic. That is, in Europe, which is experiencing seventy years of peace, not only thanks to the organisation of the European Union, but also thanks to NATO. NATO is a stabiliser for the Balkans, for the Mediterranean, including its handling of the migration crisis, but also, for example, for relations between Turkey and Greece, which could otherwise grow into open conflict. In order for NATO to continue fulfilling its role, all its Member States must fulfil their obligations, in particular to issue sufficient defence resources. The European Union and NATO must cooperate as much as possible, strengthening security guarantees for Europe and the world.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Madam President! In recent days, a video about Vienna by Viktor Orbán's minister, namely János Lázár, has been the main topic of the public debate in Austria and Hungary. As part of a cheap hate campaign, the Minister of Orbán tried to portray Vienna — one of the most beautiful cities in Europe — as if there were apocalyptic conditions in the district of Favoriten. He tried to convince Hungarian voters that the city's clean streets, as a result of the influx of migrants, were full of garbage that the real locals, so to speak, displaced — white Christians. We, the Hungarian and European democrats, want our friends in Vienna, Austria and Europe to know that the majority of Hungarians did not vote for this government. This government is in power in Hungary because of fraud and corruption. We are deeply ashamed of their agitorial speeches and apologize not only to the people of Vienna, but also to all Europeans, the representatives of the United Nations and other international organizations in Vienna, who were disgracefully insulted by Orbán's Minister.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, for about 4 months Romania has been going through an acute medical crisis due to lack of immunoglobulin on the market. This crisis, an artificial one, produced by manufacturers, importers and distributors of immunoglobulin, endangers the lives of about 5,000 patients. Fortunately, the short-term solution was found by activating the civil protection mechanism at European level. Here I must highlight the benefit of being a member of the European Union, which gives Romanian patients affected by the immunoglobulin crisis a chance at life. On the other hand, this crisis should give thought to us Europeans and wonder whether we should review at European level the relationship between the European Union and the companies producing medicines, as well as the operating rules of manufacturers and distributors . It is inadmissible that, given that the European Union budget annually supports pharmaceutical research worth hundreds of millions of euros, pharmaceutical companies blackmail national governments, making patients' right to life more fully in order to maximise their profits.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, this coming Sunday, the World Water Forum begins in Brasilia. It’s very ironic to consider that this high—level event on such a crucial issue takes place in Brazil, a country which is shifting to a dictatorship, where land-grabbing and disregard for environmental concerns are widespread. The recent decree putting the military in charge of Rio’s police, fire services and prisons is highly unlikely to solve the city’s security problem. The EU and its Member States must make a much stronger reaction to the increasing state repression. Our governments should support the Alternative Water Forum set to take place next week. This grassroots platform gathers organisations from around the world, including Green Cross, who fight for water to be recognised as a human right, rather than as a commodity. I stand in solidarity with them, and in particular with the indigenous communities in Brazil and elsewhere, who are fighting against corporations trying to seize their lands and their natural resources.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, there are two pieces of news: good and bad. The good news is that we can see rapid GDP growth in Eastern Europe, and the main reason for this growth is the contribution from EU funds. For example, in my country, Latvia, the Cohesion Fund and other European funds give around 3% GDP growth annually. Every eighth euro in the Latvian state budget is foreign help, as my colleague, the newly-appointed Member of the European Parliament, Mr Mitrofanov, knows very well. The bad news is that the economies of Eastern Europe have become heavily dependent on this money. Let us imagine that this money is not be available for a period after 2020. The reduction of Cohesion Fund spending might coincide with the next cyclical downturn in the world economy. This combination could lead to a very deep crisis in the economies of eastern EU countries. Let’s think about it.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: I declare closed the 2017-2018 session of the European Parliament.
